1. global competition and outsourcing: we live in a very well connected world. every body in any corner of the world is well connected with each other through emails, messengers etc. there is great it workforce in india which can do the same job in less money as compared to the developers in usa and europe. almost every it company outsources its lot of work to india to reap benefits by utilising the talent of india... and saves a lot of money. so, the competition in this field is global and you have to be very perfect to cope this.    2. you have to upgrade your skills continuously: technology is changing every day. everyday, there are new enhancements, everyday there is new invention. you have to keep yourself very active and updated otherwise you will be left behind in the race. you have to learn new thing everyday. you should learn to adapt with new things. standing rigid with the old things will make you lose the competition. keep on learning new programming languages and always add new thing to your resume.    3. sitting job: you have to sit tight to your desk and stare at your computer continuously. if this is not fine for you, you should not come to this profession. but today, other jobs are also becoming like this. so you will find this kind of scenario in each and every job. it can make you unhealthy very easily.    4. age discrimination: there is a lot of age discrimination in the software programming field. many people think that a person above 40 would not be able to perform well. preference is given to the young developers because it is assumed that they have fresh mind and would be able to solve the programming puzzles and tricks easily as compared to the old brains. also young developers will cost less to the companies.    5. long hours, tight deadlines and no personal and social life: in it field, you are bound to the tight deadlines and have to work for long hours and on weekends to meet the deadlines. most of the software developers have to sacrifice their personal and social life to make the deliveries on time.
new agents too raw to understand insurance
don't hire me if you don't trust me. i've always prided myself in my work ethic. but for my satisfaction not yours.

if you are a hard worker, give 100%, enjoy going into work every day to be berated, watch coworkers be berated, be told you don't work hard enough, be told you will never work hard enough, threatened on a regular basis if you are perfect, which you never will be, you will lose your job then this is the place for you.  it is a very hostile work environment.  if you work there, or have worked there, and deny this then... you are lying and you know it.
difficult and confusing system for taking leave, not being at work counts as occurrence against you, state specifics constantly changing. few opportunities to advance.

no holiday pay. lack of potential growth from the position unless you are interested in becoming an agent. set work hours and holidays. the company systems and bonus structure is very confusing and difficult to set goals.

it will likely be all you.  the vast majority of agency owners have many other priorities - and you will be selling to their clients & prospects.  start dialing agency books (warm calls) on day one,  if this does not appeal to you... this is the wrong position.  beware of the trap that you are above average (as everyone pretty much believes).  80% drop out rate at the 2 year mark.  if this were a stock investment -... would you put your money down?

unprofessional management. total disregard for employee's (support staff) feelings or concerns, and not to mention the training is sub-par. you will in essence be """"thrown into a lion's den"""".

you are not in good hands as a customer or an agent. this company took the agents that built the company and then got rid of 5,000 of them. management is a joke. they are agents for a whopping 6 months and then they know everything and try to tell you other ways to do the job that you have been doing for years. long term company plan zig zags all the time. rate increases constant. i really don't know how they have... many customers left.

i don't have any.

this past year, allstate cut their best selling type of coverage, which just so happened to be the cheapest. allstate only targets people who have had no accidents, no tickets, etc.. if you don't have one of these, then your rate is going to be pretty high. this makes it hard for me because it becomes a lot harder to compete with the other companies.

there are no advancement opportunities, medical benefits and no raises.  though i love working with the people i do, i have to think of the future as well and there aren't advancement opportunities available.

low pay. lowest paying insurance company with the highest premiums. the management at the time was poor, but they started making improvements once i left. people that are low performers are impossible to fire.

system is very backwards and hard to use. the company is no hiring right now because of claims making their budget flop. some of the management need more training/came with no insurance experience. agents are scared of the systems and the policies so you often find trash policies that need to be fixed. there is only one guy who really knows how insurance works while the rest just make guesses or call the... underwriters which also guess or tell you they are too busy to help. even supervisors and managers either brisk away from customer questions or ask that other dude. but then allstate gets mad when they have claims and agents dont know how insurance works. everyone is overworked in other departments so its hard to ask for help or more than yes or no answers...if you don't tell them exactly what you need or how to do the job they push you off and do the bare minimum. trainers mean well but they prepare you for a lot of things you wont do and then things you will do they dont spend time on.

they're pretty well known in the insurance industry for being the lowest paying company which is interesting considering that their policies are some of the most expensive - most people that work there aren't insured through them because they can't afford it unless they're higher up.  the local office in bloomington that i worked in had some serious management issues - they didn't communicate clearly with each other..., and as a result the information coming to the employees wasn't always clear.  it made for a very stressful work environment, and moral around the office truly sucked as a result.  it's not fun to go into an office every day when you know people are going to be complaining about things most of the day.
company is shrinking, diversity is questionable.  very few african americans in leadership rolls at any level.

while you can learn a lot by moving among departments, don't plan on any promotions.  allstate is medium- to low-payers, but expect you to work about 50-60 hours a week.   while you are given responsibility for the job, you are neither given the authority, nor is innovation thinking valued in any way.  documented processes are situationally followed and often conflict with one another.

platform is that you are partnered with property & casualty agents to increase their life insurance / financial services penetration by referring existing clients.  problem is, these agents are tracked on so many different metrics that obtaining the minimum is what 90% of agents strive for.  if they don't meet their monthly requirement the p&c agents pay is reduced by 10%, which means that they will refer you just... enough to write one policy that has $300 per year in premium.  i have 7 agents that i work with, and small policies like these don't even cover my bills, let alone allow me to have a comfortable lifestyle.  recruiter told me that first year efs's make $70k, and that the average efs makes $180k.  this is extremely incorrect, the first year $70,000 selling point is actually your goal for production credit not what you get paid.  if you sold $70,000 in your first year your pay would be about $45,000.  same thing with the $180,000; if you produced $180k annually you would make $120,000 which isn't bad, but it definitely is not $180k in your pocket.  the """"average"""" efs production of $180k is also skewed, there are mega-performers here who have been set-up with the only good agents in the state who produce $400-900k in production credit that make the average anything but.  the true """"average"""" efs"""" does about $120,000 in production credit and makes about $80k per year.  not a bad living, but for the amount of work / stress / etc. it is not good as they offer you no benefits, no 401k match, no health, dental, nothing.  the recruiter makes it seem as though it doesn't matter that you receive no benefits because you will be swimming in money, but thanks to obamacare, my high-deductible monthly premium is $750.
leads aren't always what they claim,  complicated bonus structure
salary is on the lower end  some departments do not have flexibility
company gives a lot, benefits, work life balance just a little light in actual cash compensation.

i feel that compensation is limited once your are in the company compared to other like sized insurers in the industry.  being a publicly traded company you will not receive the bonuses, commisions or aggressive salaries that other companies like state farm, progressive or liberty.  also this is a company where its all about who you know more so then what you know when promotion time rolls around.  limited growth... there will be 3-4 lateral moves for every vertical move that you make.

1. no learning.  2. they are not using any latest trends/tools/technologies.  3. they are ready to hire and pay for some useless roles created by their vendors already.  4. no onsite except some business trips ( such business trips are only for managers).  5. managers take decisions like snail.  6. no open source tools.   7. simply pathetic in terms of work and learning.  8. if you are stuck under a bad manager your... career is gone.    there are so many.
they will move your cheese all day long.

siloed teams, slow adoption and implementation of new capabilities, compensation should be more competitive as it is difficult for a large pay bump unless moving to a new role or via a promotion

your experience is very team-based, teams vary in terms of how they function, collaborate, and communicate. upward movement is difficult past past consultant level, it's such a huge company that it's easy to get stuck and comfortable. salary is pretty low compared with the rest of the industry, but benefits are nice - especially the amount of vacation days you get.

the pay is way too low. the pto is not enough accumulated in a year. and if you have no pto you get penalized for being sick. god forbid an emergency arises at home. no sick days and not enough pto is tough to work with.

this company typically makes bad decisions in selecting managers, who are allowed to micro-manage & intimidate employees.  if your manager doesn't care for you, don't count on raises or promotions.  they are top-heavy and may have a few token minorities or females in mid to upper management, but to join even the lower management club it's pretty much who you know, not what you know or how well you do it.  the... corporate culture is all about being super-picky to the point of ridiculousness and setting unreasonable & unreachable goals to justify punishment for performance that will never be good enough.

benefits used to be good, but costs have increased so much that you pay nearly what you pay getting your own coverage. salary stinks, with negligible increases. newbies no longer get a pension. this company recently served blue cool aid at a christmas party in champagne glasses. they went from having the party at a nice restaurant, to holding it in their cafeteria. cheap with vindictive managers.
if your agency isn't hooked up with corporate then no leads will come your way. period.

old company that is stuck in its ways. many of the managers were successful 20-30 years ago and have held on to their comfortable job for the pension. these managers don't want to rock the boat or risk their career on a new project, so things move very slowly.    the top 25% of talent is not adequately compensated for their abilities. the top 5% of talent is promoted very quickly through the very limited management... spots at allstate. the next 20% of talent occasionally gets an analyst promotion (~10% pay increase and no new responsibilities) and maxes out their annual merit increase (~7% per year). this group could make substantially more at a start-up-style company.    the best workers don't have much work-life balance, but the typical 9-5 employee does not progress in their career. at allstate, you really have to choose between the two.

work weekends, very busy days, calls back to back, numbers driven, all about numbers and goals. no growth opportunity if you have experience. upper management tends to overlook tenure employees for outside candidates with no experience simply because they are a family member. micro managing. less than average salary
no benefits for small agencies, expect rapid ramp up to successful sales quota.
the company is going through some transformation which is great, but not everyone is on the same page. lots of politics within management and you definitely have to play the game to get ahead.
have to find creative ways for growth initiatives  not necessarily a """"true"""" con but have to improve upon competitive pay

where to start. gone are the days when the company truly cared about it's employees. they just dumped the pension benefit they had since the inception of the company. yes wall street loved that they did so. but now young employees are not staying as there's little incentive to do so. the company is too process driven in my opinion and relies too much on analysts and think tanks rather than on the experience of their... employees. salaries are not competitive even though they say they are  and it takes a long time to move up the salary ladder. typical increases in claims are zero to 2%. the cost of medical benefits continues to rise (not entirely their fault) but with little increase in salary employee paychecks are getting smaller. the only opportunity for advancement really is to move to chicago which really limits what's available. the company continues to bleed it's experienced employees in favor of younger, cheaper employees who don't stay. employment in the claims department is highly stressful with processes that are more important at times than people. there is little in the way of solid benefits/rewards in claims compared to other jobs in the market particularly in the public sector which have better benefits and compensation than this company which requires a degree for an entry level position. the company also seems reluctant to embrace the mobile environment and when they do it's very sparsely done.

more work than people to do it. no opportunity to move around in the company once you reach a certain salary so you become stuck in a position and can never get out.  allstate would rather hire someone with no experience off the street for $36000 than transfer someone making $60000 to an lateral opening. promotional opportunities are not great and you usually have to be very mobile to take advantage of them. lots of... favoritism and minorities have a better chance at promotions as well. this company is stuck in processes that do not make  a lot of sense and change takes forever as home office takes forever to sign off on anything. adjusters are so specialized that customers have to talk to 4 different people to just settle their claim.  training is minimal and does not always address all you need to know.
low salaries. not trusted management.

i was a contractor there for 5 months. a mid manager had got the permission to hire some contractors and she was incompetent and junior for the role that all five contractors left after a few months. just to give the clear image, we were five contractors between 5 to 9 months working there and all in 6 figure salaries and during this time non of us had a single task to do or any deliverable . i am just shocked that... how come in such a big organization a junior person gets this much authority to hire very expensive staff to do nothing. her objective was to make territory by having a team an d at the end it didn't happen because no one stayed with her.
horrible pay, inconsistent time keepers, incorrect 0aychecks
super difficult to grow book of business with retention factoring in. no benefit package for agency owners, treats you as a contact employee

pay is bad compared to other insurance companies. changed bonus structure so bad that barely any one gets bonus. everyone has to work saturdays. other comps give 28 days pto nd benefits day 1. here you get 12 days pto and benefits after 90 days to a year
helping people, busy all day

(kissing butt is a good quality). the hours are terrible mostly 2nd shift and always working weekends. their attendance policy is stricter than any company i've ever worked for. it sucks being hired near the holidays as well with little to no... pto given for new employees.
hard to get good leads.  customers are flaky.

the company hates the claims department. the managers hate the employees. if a manager has an idea you must agree that it is great. an employee with the same idea is ignored. management makes employees work late & weekends, but managers don't have to be there. they are constantly trying to fit 2 gallons of water in a 1 gallon jug & there is no excuse for not being able to fit 14 hours of work into an 8 hour day.... management tells employees on a daily basis that they can and will be fired for anything they feel like & if someone is fired, the employees are not allowed to ever mention the former employee in the office again, or they too will be let go. everyone walks on eggshells. a horrible place to work.
workload can be extremely intense and work-life-balance can be an issue.
not the most competitive auto rates for all prospects

work-life balance sucks! you will work each and every saturday, using your pto days is so hard to do because almost everyday is blocked, high-volume calls even in the 4th quarter.

reductions if force (rif) occur at least every two years.  more and more jobs are outsourced to offices in ireland and india.  except for recent grads, career advancement is almost an impossibility.  excessive workload results in many employees not being able to use their vacation days.

i quit my 3 1/2 year job and accepted a $3. pay cut to work at allstate todd robichaux in metairie,  la. office.  my 1st week working at the office (technically 4 days) i never saw or spoke to the agent. i dealth with the rude, unprofessional, no customer service skills office manager cheryl, who felt since she has been there for 15 years she can treat employees and customer's rudely. needless to say it wasn't... working out. i was terminated my 4th day of employment by text due to downloading a halloween screensaver from the computer which supposedly caused a virus. i was told i wasn't able to ask the computer tech guy what caused the virus. i still haven't gotten paid for my 4th day working at allstate nor a termination letter.

considering the allstate brand one would think the atmosphere would be professional at a higher percentage of time than it actually was. also, the politics was atrocious and blatantly in favor of a few.

giant corporation with lots of red tape to make any changes.  not exactly on the cutting edge of technology.
no management around to make sure everybody does their work.   poor training and expectations are not clear.  support from management is poor.
long hours, a difference in commission rates where independent agents get paid 50 percent more and really do own their book, and cannot be terminated with 90 days notice without cause.
there is no where to go, you have to purchase a store in order to move up.  becoming an allstate employee is hard, as most are """"subcontractors""""

horrible management!  if you don't kiss up, you are not going anywhere.  it's all about who you know, not what you know!  over the last five years they have gotten rid of higher paid employees stating rif or positions not needed, only to turn around and hire younger people at a 1/3 of the cost.  i've seen dedicated employees with 15-25 years of service thrown to the curb, only to be replaced by a 20-something with barely any experience.  it's sickening!

too many leadership changes. every time a new leader gets transferred into a department they want to make their mark and end up changing too much. leaders never stay in one place long enough and the employees suffer.  impacts efficiencies, and progress...

working at allstate can be draining - the servicing of customers is shoved to the agency at all times, under the guise of 'giving the customer more access to the agency'. this is great - except during peak times, this can create a significant backlog and some high stress tensions to run through the agency staff.

p.c. agents have new financial producers introduced to them almost every week.  you are told you can work with as many different p.c. agents as you like, but due to jaded agents (high turnover of financial reps), good luck getting any business referred to you.  two or three financial guys get 95% of all the business.  it is very hard to get referrals.  so, you are basically doing all your own production at half the... comp. you would earn if you were independent.    in addition, just because someone has general liability insurance doesn't mean there are good candidates for life, disability, long-term care or financial services.  remember you are in a sophisticated business.  anyone can buy general liability insurance.        horrible technology systems.
because it's so small to work for an agent, there are times its very much not flexible. there's little movement for upward growth within an agency.
very weak training, no support, captive contract
work culture differs by area.  not the most exciting work.
management has too much input and little helpful information to contribute.  too many chiefs!

where do i start? you'd think a large company like allstate would have enough """"good hands"""" to help their customers at the call centers.. not so! charlotte is pretty much the defacto call center that handles the majority of call flow throughout the country.. let me repeat that. the. entire. country. there are two other call centers but they are more so auxiliaries with different roles.. texas handles outbound and... idaho.. well, the verdict is still out on what management wants to do with them considering they're looking at changing a lot of roles there.     charlotte is bleeding employees, it's sad. recent reorganization and focus in operations to satisfy disgruntled agents is backfiring big time and now employees are being tasked to cover up mismanagement by  higher ups and are becoming fatigued. customer reps are absorbing more duties that were outside their roles. combine this with tom wilson's love of premium increases to enrage customers and you got a recipe for a interesting, if not, wicked interaction between irritated reps and broke customers. due to the long layover time to train people there's been difficulty in maintaining adequate levels for call handling. going to work on saturdays is like walking the green mile right into hades.
very fast paced and demanding.
no room for career growth at the support staff level
heavy work load, upper management unrealistic about goals.
corporate management is terrible at making decisions. this directly impacts sales.
in some areas, there is so much overlap of job and department responsibilities that there is a lot of infighting and politics involved in getting anything done.
pay... i hate to say that they are not super competitive in most areas.
promoting within is very challenging! management is very deceptive and shady.
the pay isn't that great.  don't do it without a second income in the household!

long hours, with being put in many difficult customer service situations. the quality of local management deteriorated during final years. hard decisions were not supported, local managers went out of their way to find fault, and kept pressure up to and extent where quality of life becomes impossible to manage. auto adjusters at allstate are treated poorly, which sadly is becoming an industry standard.
decisions don't get made quickly, and they are often made at the top of the organization without input from lower level employees.
making 80 to 100 cold phone calls per day  rigid
great opportunities for upward movement in the company.  great environment to work in.

you are expected to work and work hard all of the time.  above and beyond is the expectation and not necessarily always rewarded.  after 25yrs i was laid off, thank god, and the benefits going out the door were generous but i found that i had sacrificed too much of my life and my family suffered because i was always working or always on call to go to work.  i expressed a concern about flying to a catastrophe... location because there was still weather (hurricane) in the area and some flights were cancelled.  i was told i should rent a car and drive.  after that i was described as being afraid to fly!  management often has their head in hard to access places when it comes to assessing what their field staff is doing.

as with any large company, there is a lot of red tape, approvals and unnecessary processes. this makes things move very slowly, and it is hard to move projects along. also, this is a hierarchal company, so if you do not like that, this is not the place for you.
difficult to advance unless you in the old boys network.  honesty and dedication and trumped over career hungry colleagues who will do anything to get ahead.

hr dis not know their job and gave bad advise.  corporate did not care to make good.  i left because my mother had a stroke. i was advised via email to resign.  i did that when the advice should have been submit fmla papers for a leave which i was already on to take her to appointments.  when i was ready i never got called, told i am re-hire-able yet they dont want to hire me because i resigned. even with documented... proof and good status i was not allowed back. maybe i should call a lawyer. also, i heard compensation went down. thats sad
slow sales, no benefits, schedules can be changed often depending on the sales. if your sales are slow, the agent can get anxious and change your schedule to work evenings and weekends.
depending on the agents you get, new hires will get the bottom producers.
very political; all about whether you are liked
horrible team leader. racism. discrimination. bad mouthing about other people. favoritism.
stressful and only for motivated individuals
leadership across business areas is not always aligned.  too much red tape in the way of getting important projects implemented.

overall the company is good, but i was in a terrible group. 5 people out of 10 were fired or quit. had a terrible manager who was not liked by anyone, but was friends with her boss. made my life very difficult, and i was forced to take a job elsewhere. hr just had a 50 percent reduction and was too busy to listen to any feedback, or provide any training to managers.
i don't have any cons to contribute.

this is soley based on the ato/etrm positions. there is little or no training for most positions. the responsibilities and the processes of how to do them are ever changing. allstate is not set up for people to work well remotely yet our jobs demand it. the work/life balance is sorely out of wack for exempt personal.

not the most exciting job on the planet assisting people with insurance. the owner of my agency was fantastic and that made all the difference in the world.  the trainings at corporate were great and they brought in some great speakers for seminars during the course of my employment.
benefits are good but health insurance is getting more challenging with the industry
pay was well below the chicago market.
low base pay for the position, very corporate - in that they loose focus on you as an individual and you become just a number and they lose sight on internal customer focus.
the cons are you are overworked and underpayed. the environment is hostile.
agency does not compensate well for about of responsibility
older company which means things move slower. some employees speak up some don't about issues. the culture change from old beige and dusty to new, hip and clean is moving to slow.
none that i have come across
the commission structure did change a little too often and not for the better.
diversity challenged and senior management does not care about employees

corporate has a tight grip...everything has to be done their way, their computer system programs aren't the best, not paid enough for what they expect from you, a lot of older people who have been doing it the same way for 20 years try to slow progress. overall a good first job, not really worth a career unless you really want to be an agent.
need more work in career advancement   structure is limiting some and a helping a few  just a little more work to make this place awesome
the work can become somewhat boring and monotonous at times, due to the nature of insurance business. this is something that is unavoidable, however.
unclear career succession, often people are promoted who have less direct experience than other candidates.  changes occur so frequently that job stability is put into question.
very little growth opportunities for a creative/marketing career path

recently told that we will only make 75% of the max for my position because they're trying to save money. lower management totally clueless to what's needed by employees. they just go through  motions and play favorites. sad to say, been here over 10 yrs and my experience hasn't been good.

many people struggle to advance at allstate.  you have to know people, impress the right people, & network effectively.  the culture can vary a lot from department to department.  you could work in one department & have complete work from home flexibility, then have it forbidden in another department where the work is identical.
too insular and not receptive to outside hire.  industry under challenge from competitors.  business outlook flat.

cheap with some claim payouts, making the job difficult for adjusters being between the claimants and their bosses.  difficult to get a decent raise, if any.  some management with cavalier demeanor, e.g. take it or leave it (hit the road- you're lucky to have a job at all) attitude.
working in a small business environment with only 7 co workers. manager manages two offices. not there when you need them.
very political with many in leadership that have individual agendas
not a great wage and raises aren't much.
limited and slow growth for career enhancement
customers were constantly difficult to deal with

after training, you're on your own... literally.  no managers around when you need anything, personal, business related, etc.  policies get changed and the manager that's supposed to inform you is on vacation for a month and the temporary manager realized the huge pay cut they were getting for being a manager and decided to go back to the phones as a regular rep to make more money.  they need structure badly.  not... to mention the """"99% sure there will be a schedule change if you're working til 1:30a""""... that was a lie.  and the bonus structure was cut in half, so you never see the potential money promised in the interview
there is quite a lot of nepotism and bureaucracy.  promotions and incentives are mostly based on who you know and/or who you are related to instead of performance and merit.
office politics, obsessive management, unrealistically high standards
as with any large company it's not as nimble as it can be. career advancement can take time.
call center environment  work life balance

due to the nature of allstate being such a large company, change takes time. allstate is on the brink of really positive culture change, however in some regards it is not happening as quickly as i would like to see it. that being said, it is definitely pointed in the right direction!
very dysfunctional company. if they had not grown so large while they were a part of sears, this model now would never have lasted. direction from the top is a disaster, no clue or integrity.
very big company to navigate.

working at allstate has been an overall positive experience. i love that’s it’s a big company with lots of people to meet and ideas to absorb but that fact that it is so big can be overwhelming at times. there are so many programs to join but where do you start and how do you find the programs? i think communication is an opportunity area.

leadership has not consideration or regards in keeping what is promised to new coming agents. they will say and do anything to bring you in. they will make sure that you spend all the revenue you generated selling their policy is spend in marketing the agency to find reasons to take over your customers and let you go with one time buy back. over priced insurance, hard to sell.

management is not always receptive to new ideas. our old senior team has been replaced with new outside people..best thing to happen to company..also advancement is impossible once you've exhausted promotion within your pay group...stuck until you either get promoted or decide to leave
didn't move up the ladder easily.
horrible management, low salary, horrendous work volume, no room for growth, you are expected to work for free on your personal time and unknowledgeable managers

extremely high volume of claims, constantly felt behind, like i would never catch up.  dealing with angry, frustrated claimants all day was emotionally & mentally exhausting.  sitting in a cubicle, looking at a computer screen all day got old pretty fast, too.
angry customers .. a lot, pay was not as high as expected but still decent, hard to explain to customers why we keep taking rate increases.
advancement at mid management and up
low pay, not much room for growth (unless you want to buy an agency or work for corporate)

the worst place i have ever worked!! allstate takes micro management to a new level. i left the company for another and can safely say the grass is greener on the other side. if you have the opportunity to leave do it. it is a sinking ship.
working for an independent agent
have to get used to being with such a large corporation.
limited growth potential, if you are looking to make more than 30k you need to open your own office and incur the overhead expense of doing so.
in an insurance agency, you are limited on the time of year you can take a vacation because the boss always get the first choice of days off and he or she can take off as much as they like.

-claim volume varies. sometimes when it's dead, you may just get 3 or 4 claims a day. when we have a catastrophe of some kind, we can get as many as 10 claims a day. 1 day, i got 15 claims in 1 day. when the claims come in bunches like that, it is very hard to keep up, and if you don't put the extra time in, you can easily get lost in the shuffle and get weeks behind. if you get majorly behind, it can take weeks if... not months to catch yourself back up.   -you are never caught up. even when you think you are good, something always happens, and falling behind is just part of the job.   -management doesn't always understand what adjusters are having to deal with. there are always things on top of things that they require of us and don't realize that it takes away from the bottom line, which is to service the customer in a timely manner.   -meetings=too many of them. most meetings are pointless and only lead to adjusters falling further behind in their workload.   -long hrs. although you could work just 8-9 hr. days, you would fall very far behind and would spend 1/2 a year trying to catch back up. you are almost forced to work 10-12 hr. days to catch yourself up and keep yourself from falling behind. luckily, cat pay helps even out the need to work these long hrs.
some of the coworkers were unfriendly but fortunately for me i only had to work with them for an hour before they left for home.
lousy management from top to bottom.
a lot of corporate red tape and needless paperwork

senior people are being laid off on a regular basis and done in a manner that the company does not need to report it. salary below industry standards. the employees are looking over their shoulders wondering if they will be in the next batched to be walked out the door.  extremely low moral. very little advancement. the good ole boy system is in full swing even thought the company has tried to get away from it.
very conservative, slowly starting to change company culture

employee performance and feedback discussions are weak and not very actionable.  goal setting process across organization needs a lot of improvement for employees to believe they are even close to being attainable.  also, if you are not in the """"in group"""" your advancement opportunities are seriously disadvantaged.
you are made to feel easily replaceable, and constantly live in fear of being outsourced. it feels more like a grade school class room than a company.
none yet, just starting with the company
collaboration is not a priority

it managers are penny wise and dollar foolish.  the good people leave for other companies and some dead wood stays on for years.  non it trained people in management seats have made some poor decisions as they do not possess the it knowledge to see the long term consequences of some actions.
the pay is very low for the industry standars and all that is expected of you.
management changes ever 12-18 months, continual disruption, poor morale, can't seem to figure out what the want the company to be
no one will tell you the truth about the success/fail ratio of new agents.  it is miserable.  have very deep pockets and be prepared to be broke for 7 to 10 years.

high work volume, sometime unreasonably high expectations/goals, doesn't take full advantage of technology to keep excellent high performing employees with the company.

too much outsourcing in technology department  multiple layoffs, occurring almost quarterly  due to outsourcing, limited opportunities for upward movement at northbrook location  very political working environment

*benefits: related to other claims jobs, you pay a much higher percent of benefit cost and it gets very expensive.  they try to claim the vacation is great and it is, for the first year but they combine vacation and sick time so it looks like a lot but stacked up to other companies it is slightly below average.  finally, the 401k used to be great.  they would match 50 cents to $1.50 for every dollar you contribute.  they changed it 3 years ago an no one (not even hr) really understands it.  it is no longer based on profit, it is based on how they perform on some industry index that no one understands.  you get paid between 25-50 cents on the dollar for the first 3 percent you contribute and then like 10-35 cents for the next 2 percent.  i think i was matched about 35 cents on the dollar which is terrible.    *compensation: i think it starts at $38k a year which is good for a college grad.  raises, here are none.  when there are, they are usually insulting.  """"top performers"""" can expect 2.5 percent every other year or so.  it's not even enough to keep up with inflation.  they usually allow an offices salary to go up by 1.5 percent which means the average raise has to be 1.5 percent.  some people will get 2 percent.  most get 0.  99 percent of """"promotions"""" are lateral meaning no raise.  if you go from handling non-injury claims to injury claims you get not a dollar more even though you take on twice the work.  it's insane.  there are no real bonuses or incentives other than your pay check.  i won employee of the month several times and got a $5 gift card.    *micro-management: most of the industry uses scripts but allstate lives by them.  if you deviate from the script at all (even if you get the wording wrong) and someone listens to your call, you will be told your performance is not satisfactory.  they are taking administrative tasks like time keeping and stuff away from managers so they can spend more time micro-managing and coaching.  they will record calls, track number of calls and how long and context does not matter to them.    *no opportunities: not one person was promoted to management at any point i was with allstate.  they are actually going down managers right now on purpose so don't think you can get promoted in 5-20 years because you won't.  be happy being an adjuster because that is all you ever will be.    *culture: they are going through """"culture change"""" over the last two years.  but no one can tell you what that means so they just label everything culture change.  it's actually funny.  they will change staples in the stapler and then let everyone know and call it culture change.  they said they wanted to move the focus back to happy employees but they have done just the opposite.  our office turn over has jumped dramatically.  they said they wanted to encourage movement outside of claims to get good people where they can do the most good but of the 10 people i know of who wanted to try to transfer, all were told no because they were needed too much in their current role.  it is a catch-22.  if you are great at your job, they won't let  you transfer because they can't lose you.  if you are bad at your job, they obviously won't let you transfer.  my advice, be average and fly under the radar.    *this is sort of culture/management: this is a typical example of the type of stuff they do.  for 5 years they were pretty flexible with start times.  you don't clock in or anything.  if you were a few minutes late, no biggy.  you just stayed a few minutes late to make up for it.  no one abused it.  without warning, our office boss decides he is going to change that but he doesn't tell anyone.  what he does do, he has a manager go through the phone log in time (which we were never required to log into right away) and the security log to see what time people swiped their key card (even though people always walked in together).  if you swiped your key card more than 1 second after your start time, you were given an occurrence.  he actually went back 6 months and handed out occurrences like they were going out of style.  90 percent of the office was written up.  just think about how many times in the last 6 months you have opened the door at work 1 second late.  if that answer is more than 3, you are in big big trouble and being considered for termination.
poorly trained, inflexible ,not so bright,psychotic management.  my manager was an expert in gaslighting, and has lawsuits pending against her regarding her abhorrent behavior.
pay could be higher and it is tough to work without two days off in a row.

by no fault of the agency owner, the rates were not too competitive.

it all depends what p&c agent one is partnered with.  if the agent wants to help you, they will refer clients to you.  if not, then you are just another financial advisor without a book of business.
pay rate is terrible and they treat employees like slaves. you sometimes have to work weekends as well

in my experience, i've been encouraged to get involved in employee resource groups (ergs) and network with others inside the company, only to be told that i'm """"all over the place"""" and """"socializing with friends"""". i was also told that i am coming up with every reason to not do my job.     however, they clearly ignored the fact that in order to get this """"software application"""" properly tested by my team, i had to gather... the right requirements from all the right teams. so this required various meetings, which obviously kept me away from my desk.     so in a nutshell, they tell me i'm slacking and not doing my job. even if the time i wasn't at my desk, was actually spent in meetings in order to actually do my job.      my manager and team have not given me the direction and guidance i need to succeed. as a new employee to allstate, and recent college graduate. i would expect a challenging environment, but i wasn't expecting this.     i've felt like i have been set up for failure. there have been no clear expectations and the performance feed back i've gotten has clearly come from individuals that do not have my best interest at heart. if anything, i believe there are individuals that are taking things out on a personal level. which i think is inappropriate and unprofessional.

in claims we worked some nights and weekends, if you could not move you could not advance any higher than a supervisor type position, working with injured people who are trying to bleed you dry is kind of a drag after a while, it leaves you jaded.
very high rates in the florida market, brutal guidelines, writing policies is like pulling teeth.
need more training on property services

what once used to be a great company to work for is changing for investors, but not for employees.  constantly cutting costs, most of which are people.  the last five years have been a looming cloud of cutbacks.  pension and 401k were reduced.  outsourcing continues at a rapid pace.
call center typical stressful environment   constantly changing schedule
salaries are a bit low.  processes need to improve to keep up with growth.  recognition is not on par with other companies of this size.
not a pay master. can do better on bonuses!
not too much into cutting edge technologies  projects take longer to complete  very high in bureaucracy
many re-organizations  very conservative with ideas  slow to change (implementations)  no intentional succession planning

i have not found any apparent cons since i have been working at allstate. it is a large company and i would advise anyone who is new to allstate to meet and network with as many people as possible.

i'm currently in my first rotation with ldp and i'm already thinking that i don't want to move forward and i haven't even been there two weeks. my biggest thing is that they need to seriously consider who they put into what department, because where i am now everything is going over my head and i seriously think in the next month i'm not going to be there because i'm so frustrated. the systems for their analytics is... completely out of date. i should not have accepted the position in the first place and now i regret it. i honestly don't want to deter anyone from allstate, but i think that before you go into any position you seriously need to consider your options and they should as well. i'd say that my experience thus far has been horrible, the location is terrible, technology it horrible, and my overall experience thus far has not been good.
i feel on average, the pay at allstate is below the industry average.  the company is trying to cut costs wherever they can, which is leading to a lot of outsourcing.
the company seems to be getting smaller  job reclassification seems to be happening often.

some of the worst morale and pay i have seen.  senior leadership allows infighting and politics to guide most of the decision making.  it has outsourced many positions related to quality and now wonders why new software releases cause major outages.  they also cut the pay of the remaining it staff which has sent a clear message to the more talented resources to head elsewhere.    an okay place to start a career... because the vast amount of dysfunction provides great example of how not to run a profitable company.
low pay, must really push and be in a good position to move up, most positions and people they find replaceable, sometimes the performance results you receive can be out of your control

public relations gaffes, like not paying on claims, which cause a negative outlook on company.  especially after disasters like hurricanes, when the public is sensitive to these things.

the downside to allstate is that they think about career progressions very linearly. if you are hired as a financial analyst, you will follow the same career path that countless others have followed. they lack the hr wherewithal and creativity to identify or validate the true value in peoples' abilities outside of prescribed position requirements.    if you want mobility at allstate, make sure you are hired into the... area that you truly want to work in long-term.

they will raise there rates so high that it only effects the local agents.  at times they are not competitive at all. average renters insurance  $10-$13, allstate will come back around $25 dollars for the same coverage. not even competitive.

very low pay...  i could be making $15k more at other companies...  i can't even afford to get benefits! i'd be broke if i had gotten benefits.      too much red tape and bureaucratic bull to deal with.     no meaningful work...  you feel like your talents are wasted.
too much money spent on campus landscaping, etc.

many of the employees have been there for a very long time and at times are very reluctant to change. there is really no promotion unless you become a manager. some employees have had the same position for over 25 years.

- very stressful position.  sometimes you can help a customer resolve a situation, and sometimes you have to have conversations where you're telling someone whose life depends on it that the answer is no.  - first day of training they told us, """"the only thing constant at allstate is change.""""  and it's true.  your processes will change on a daily basis.  things you used to be allowed to do will be taken away.  99% of... things you need processed will have to be sent to a different department to get it done.  and don't count on that last 1% sticking around for very long.  - attention to detail and organizational skills are an absolute must.  you can't put anything off or you will fall further and further behind on your work.  - too much focus on audits, not enough focus on actually helping customers regardless of the situation.  - while the company """"supports"""" lateral moves or even promotions, you cannot apply for any new position during your first year of employment.  on average, it takes 3-5 years to get out of the asap department if you are attempting to apply for other positions on a regular basis.

i did my homework before signing on with allstate and was expecting more financially from the csr position than what actually panned out. after becoming employed i learned that each agency compensates their csrs at the level they choose. there is no allstate """"standard"""" pay schedule. i was hired at $12/hr and from other allstate reviews expected that the sop was to be bumped up after the first three months. that... didn't happen, so i found myself in a 40-hr+/week position that didn't pay enough to make the bills, even with the small bonuses from sales. i grew to know the clients and really enjoyed working in the agency, but reluctantly had to resign after 6 months due to not being able to afford to stay on.    allstate's agent support line for the agencies is terrible. when we needed information in order to resolve a customer's concern or problem with their policy; or had an issue with the allstate proprietary software/programs, calling the agent support line was an exhausting exercise in frustration. we were shuttled from person to person and each support person would give us a different """"right"""" answer. they obviously lacked the product/procedure/software knowledge neccessary to assist us. completely unacceptable, if the agency is the face of """"allstate"""" to the public, and the agency personnel don't receive the necessary support to help the customer and build their confidence in the brand. corporate is aware of the problem but moves extremely slowly to address known issues.

if you're not in good with upper management, you're not moving up within the cic.   work/life balance can be tough, especially for single mothers.   don't expect the book to be open to use random pto until after the second half of the year.
needs to be a higher pay rate and more opportunity for growth
work schedule, processes, culture, robotic

this is a meeting heavy culture. usually you won't get work done until you go home. people are promoted based on politics. if the staff doesn't like you for reasons unrelated to performance such as the way you dress, how you talk, or if you don't wear make up they will find a reason to get rid of you. you have to leave the organization and come back in order to get a promotion faster. in the technology department... the work never stops especially if you are on a deployment you have to work over the weekend. you will get a different day off if you do work over the weekend. they won't pay you market rate salaries even if you have the experience. usually the insurance industry never pays you market rate. the last 3 years have been rifs and people have been re-banded and demoted. their salaries have been categorized into lower levels so people that were making 6 figures are back to 5 figures. you have to realize right now allstate is losing customer and money so of course they are getting rid of people. if they bring in entry-level employees they pay them the same amount they paid them 14 years ago. it's not enough to keep up with the cost of living. many people are leaving the company right now. if you are new to the company you will get an orientation but not much training. don't be surprised if you do administrative work instead of your actual job. this is a company that doesn't like to change. if you have good ideas they are not usually implemented if it means changing the existing technology systems. everyone is worried about their job s so people keep good information to themselves and they won't share it with others to protect their jobs. the performance system is set up to make sure a few people fail at the bottom so even if everyone does a really good job someone has to fail.
must pass state insurance test by week 2   all departments have a sales goal   customer service department is all sales too
only lateral movements are available, large amount of favoritism
not what you know, but who you know gets you far
just becomes repeative and boring and because they normaly pay more than other call centers they tend to keep you very busy!

upper management changes the product so often that you're spending all day dealing with retention instead of getting new business.  although i think steady work hours is a good thing, for me they are really steady-- can't work from home, can't take a day off, can't work flex time.  many colleagues are not adept enough at technology so i spend a lot of time doing things the old, slow way, like printing instead of... scanning and emailing, looking up paper files in a filing cabinet.  many agents are older so they don't know new systems, leaving me to do all quoting, looking up policies, or any other computer-based work which means we spend twice as much time to do a task than if they just did it themselves.
no work life balance.  compensation was not fair compared to all the work that had to be accomplished.

i started off with some of the best management team ever, but over years it became worse and worse as leaders move on. management is rotated so often that by the time you teach them what is needed they move on. most managers only worry on the mark they leave. slogans are becoming so pathetic they smell. one year """" power of one"""", next slogan """"power of one and then some""""  workload is unmanageable but no one cares.... recognition from coworkers is good but recognition from management is virtually non existent. you are more likely to get noticed for organizing an outing then for performing on the job.  in 10 years it went from the best to pathetic...
pay, is not competitive but fair.
they don't offer much benefits. it also seems like the company is not very organized. sometimes agents promise customer things the company does not offer.

upper management is rarely around and when they are they don't want the truth about what is going on in the units. they keep bad managers on at the expense of the employees. morale is low and people don't complain becuase there is a sense you will be """"blackballed."""" there are a lot of people there 20+ years so you will not get vacation time when you want it. you will have to work weekends. the claim volume is crazy.... they care more about customer service scores and contact numbers than claim file quality.     if you have an option other than allstate take it.
recent outside managers being hired do not have the people skills nor do they value the allstate culture.  however, they are knowledgeable in the areas they were hired for so it makes business sense
the company is sinking - they keep raising rates up up up but get mad when you do not produce new policies. how are you supposed to compete when progress and geico have you beat by as much as 200%?
no respect to their independent agents, and frustrating when trying to work with the agent customer service line.

when i first started at allstate i had such great hopes only to find out that they were a revolving door for those that came in at the level i came in on. the work was interesting and challenging but the environment was not professional at all. it really saddened to experience such lack of professionalism from management.

-numerous broken promises about money to be made and which partners i would work with.  -very young manager, very difficult to get a hold of  -they say they want to do investment business, but it is not true they are not set up at all to do investments.  -very poor computer systems.  very poor support for agents and fs.  -no humans to talk to unless you got thru 10 prompts with voice robots.  -sorry to say this but... very low percentage of employees who have completed college.
your contract is one sided and allstate senior management is out of touch with everything.

let people use their critical thinking skills sometimes, rather than rely on rules and computers all the time.  (i'm talking about underwriting here)  it would be nice to be credited with having a brain and decision making skills.  also, systems are outdated and need upgrading - that would be nice.
hard to move up in the company. pay is not as great as other insurance industries.
irrational decisions made by executives
you need to be young to see a good promotion. kind of clickish and biased against older workers.

not enough people understand the business of insurance and the ones that did are no longer there. unfortunately the current leadership doesn't understand that this problem is critical.
senior management needs to understand we are nothing without our customers and the frontline employees.the technology hinders us instead of helping.
