heavy workload.  look at numbers instead of people.  all to willing to terminate long time employees.
employees like it so much, advancement rearly happens because no one leaves.

-stressful work load  -customers no longer matter, how do i look when telling my loyal customer that due to their good credit and safe driving record your policy renewal increased 92% oh and it's because of the area your live in.   -unrealistic goals.   -working with my 4th allstate independent agent after the previous three where forced out or forced to retire  for various reasons.  -over worked 10 to 12 hour days... are the norm for me. leave on time and become the black sheep.  -unpaid morning meetings  -terrible benefits package.   -actually using said pto is a task in itself. it took me 7 months to finally take a my weeks vacation as there was always something within the office preventing me from taking it.  -profits over employees and customer loyalty

to be successful you will need to make a large capital investment.  must be prepared for a lot of work in the sales field.  the company is not loyal to its agency owners and will fire them if they do not meet multiple requirements that change and are often unclear.
for promotions there was a premium based upon politics (who likes who) and not performance competence.

who makes the decisions on promotions?  rewarded heroism as opposed to strategic planning.  my offboarding from the company is a complete joke.  i'm now 8 weeks from when i gave my 3 week notice and i'm still dealing with hr on issues.  when i left, i had an open mind about coming back.  after this last experience, i would never go back by choice.
work load is tremendous   stressful job  work hours are not consistent  late evening hours required  weekend duty hours required by allstate
in recent years, allstate has lost its way and employee morale has suffered due to multiple layoffs over the past 4 - 5 years.

the business model is failing and the company is currently having a difficult time adapting.  stated growth objectives do not always align with company actions - can leave employees confused about true goals.   objectives and goals seem to change and even reverse rapidly.  the company has a tendency to want to """"spin"""" excessively.   company struggles at any true organic growth, and efforts to grow are causing ongoing... bad decisions.  high leadership turnover recently  has left me increasingly feeling disconnected from the company - amputated.  i used to feel much more connected but can't seem to get on the same wavelength as current leadership and it leaves me feeling less useful as an employee.  there is concern that me or my department is not in the future plans any longer.
incompetent leadership  too many leadership changes

almost always very demanding and stressful, along with repetitive and mind-numbing. as long as you know your limits and don't let yourself get burnt out - because you will catch up to all the work you have to do - you'll do great.
when a customer complains about a rental issue that you have no control over you are also still held accountable, so sometimes that stinks

-senior leadership in my specific department seemed amateur-ish. like they don't have a handle on things.  -favoritism can be very very apparent. regardless of your performance you may end up on the losing side.
no benefits, no training, very strict underwriting guidelines sudden large rate increases make it hard to sell

for those coming in with no experience, salary is low compared to other companies. allstate recently bumped up the entry level pay band but even after that is still paying below competitors.   goal-setting has become overly ambitious. its impossible for adjusters to hit new goals implemented no matter how efficient and diligent or how many over time hours you put in.

senior leadership without breath of experience.  80/20 rule applied to projects is great, but when applying employee cuts to those assigned to the 20% of the projects they had no choice to avoid, unfair.
management is very strict and always keeps a watchful eye on you. it is hard to move up within the company without proper connections.
- limited career advancement as the company is struggling with the top line results  - the prolonged reduction-in-force process results in poor morale

new pay structure is the same for everyone (no """"hot"""" career fields are rewarded in it despite tons of outside opportunities), managed by fear, always waiting for the next negative announcement, entry leadership positions are with little to no decision making ability or pay increase - merely write reviews for team members and take the fall if they screw up, morale is at rock bottom, leadership is clueless that... talented people are leaving in droves and has been defensive when the subject is discussed, outsourcing is a priority and helping the company to increase outsourcing is something employees are reviewed on, company has a culture of regular leadership changes (in short time intervals) so continuity is non-existent, i have witnessed 8 oranizational changes in the last 10 years - it's like trying to hit a moving target, company has a culture of not using lessons learned for the benefit of future efforts.  was one a company with some dysfunction (like most large companies have) but had great people who made things work extremely well.  in the last few years, it has become a company with severe dysfunction and many good people with talent and options are leaving willingly because they see the downward spiral.

leadership seems unable to grow the business  budget shortfalls result in work stoppages  reduction in force imminent  no assurance of job security as in days gone by   off-shoring, off-shoring, off-shoring
rates are not competitive. company has lost respect for employees. allstate is losing market share rapidly and the value of the agency is dropping- 30% in last 3 years.
dealing with agency staff and owners can be difficult, 100% commission can be hard to deal with, needing others to help you become succesfull does't always work out.

upper management out of touch with the reality of the work place.  double standard when doing good work.  they will not advance you because you can not be replaced, yet will look to fire you because you have never advanced.

management drives you, lies to you and tells you that there is promise of advancement in your future. once the task is complete (you know the one that no one wanted to do so you got suckered into it) management forgets you exist.
more feedbac from upper level management about work production. not too much favortsm, however from time to timeis doeshappen and it is noticeable.

benefits have deteriorated and not longer competitive and more out of pocket from employees without giving them raises.  401k match  now based on customer service instead of company financial status means less money  upper management is too focused on process and are out of touch with the field  focus on expense reduction at the expense of employees is not helping the company grow  claims employees now working... weekends and holidays  pay once you've reached the mid point is very difficult to increase.
zero prioritiazation of work and budget
too much , me ,not team work, inclusive of management
you'll never see a raise after you reach your midpoint and you'll never reach the top of your pay grade.  the yearly reviews are a joke.
work environment very structured, asked for more work and not given

work weekends  if u call out sick u get an tude  they dont care about employees  management has no idea on what to do,  if they were to take 1 phone call from begining of a claim to the end, they would have no idea what to say.  they do not stick up for there employees  all they do is put you down  and if a customer is upset and they want to """"talk to yout manager""""  the manager will never take the call and i mean... never,  they can care less about the fact that employees have lives and family  i can write a ten page letter about how bad allstate ins company is to work for

too many people doing too little, old fashioned, slow/hard to change, senior leadership is disjointed, the new president micromanages, frustrating culture if you are not satisfied with the status quo.
a lot of change through out all departments on a regular basis.
- too much outsourcing  - lack of ownership  - no promotions  - chicago traffic  - too much paperwork  - insurance image
allstate does not do enough for the newer agency owners. they don't care about their policy holders only their stock holders.
leadership now is not as strong or supporting of employees as in the past  devaluing of older workers and employees in general  promotions often based on personal preferences vs talent

salary compensation is lower than other insurance companies.  no bonuses either.  they focus on """"total compensation"""" which includes the medical benefits, 401k + pension plan and generous time off.  however, for younger employees, it's hard to justify a better retirement package when they are just starting their careers.
too political, it's who you know not what you know
senior leadership is to far removed from the claims atmosphere.
hours are not good for everyone, and the leadership of local management is very poor - play favorites and favortism too much.

promotions at the management level are political, salaries are not competitive especially if you stay with the company for a while, layoffs are getting ever more common.  the risks associated with staying with allstate for the long term are outweighing the benefits.  talented employees are seeing this and looking for the door after a few years.  experienced employees are putting their experience to work for... competitors and other companies.
few if any health or retirement benefits and little room for advancement. the only way to increase earnings is through constantly making more sales.
little opportunity for advancement-100 people posting for the same few positions (promotions) that are offered every year. it's a rat race.   it's who you know, not what you know  dead end
management will stab you in the back.  they only care about the bottom line
planning season will require very long hours, but they usually try to show some recognition for that

have been working in an allstate agency for 2 years now and it is very upsetting to see how incompetent the agents are. working as a customer service rep. i deal with problems on a daily basis, but what is really sad that 90% of the problems brought on the office is by the agent herself. but this is isnt the first agent that i have worked for that seems to have no clue how to run a business. i came in a with a... certain impression and have been very disappointed!

limited growth, no increased commission, their cic department will make after hours sales for you but you will only receive 3.5% commission of the 10% you'd normally receive.  you must maintain unrealistic internal goals that you have no control over.
but if you want to learn then you are on your own. there are many technologies here but you will need to learn by yourself

management is unprofessional and do not know anything!  they claim to hire the best, yeah right! they hire anyone who is stupid enough to stay!  it is a sweat shop, all work no play!  the only thing that separates you from a telemarketer is a license!  people in the hr office are worthless & don't know anything!  you call on the same leads over and over!  managers hover and listen in on your calls, then hassle you... on how it could of been better, but they haven't spent a minute on the phone doing your job!
in certain positions you were limited to when you could take time off due to business needs.  this it totally understandable, but when my children were in school it was a challenge.
middle & upper management communication

this place does not care about employees (and probably not the customers either).  stockholders are 'king'.   only care is cutting expenses, so that ceo (and bonus level officers) can get their bonuses.  ceo rec'd 30% increase in income for 2009, after cutting 1000's of employees (and losing customers and policies in force).       morale is at an all-time low, favoritism and brown-nosing culture.  they are a 'good... ol boys network'.  several million dollar projects are started, then aborted each year.  the strategic planning is horrendous.  millions are wasted annually - with stops/starts - then with no implementations.  to make budget for the next year, they make more cuts (but the gains or efficiencies are never achieved).  nice environment - eh???

employee morale is low due to highly visible favoritism  sr leadership in finance dept  needs leadership training as well as etiquette on speaking with non-leadership staff - they often speak with demoralizing demeanor   corporate life becomes very gruesome when fighting for budget dollars and headcount - they act like it is the end of the world and become nasty to work with.   not a place for people who get their... feelings hurt easily.    stop the finger pointing and work together to get the work done.

promotes """"good hands"""" and work/life balance but only interest is bottom line and stock price. often senior leadership put personal bonus ahead of sound business decisions. talks the talk but does not walk the walk.    leadership is living in the past and allowing competition to pass them by.

management is not held responsible for there actions.    the benefits compared to other insurance companies is far below what fellow insurance people are receiving in the local area.  employee recognition is like working at walmart.  you get a parking spot.    the professionalism that had existed is no longer here.    it really is about making yourself look good.      outsourcing is high on the list why not work for... this company.  i would of thought they would of learned their lesson with outsourcing to the phillipines and having to pull the jobs back to the states.
always a possibility of the job you're in being relocated either elsewhere in the country or outsourced to other country
outsourcing. to people that had completely no clue on what they were doing.  the company did this to save money but it hurt rather then helped
some of the customers get rude, its stressful at times. it can also be very competitive as you are doing the same thing every day.

pay is terrible, very much a military culture, orders come from top and are executed. little freedom for product or state managers to try new ideas. company is too conscerned about short term profits. you have to be in with the right people to have a chance at getting promoted to senior levels. they don't pay for performance.
commuting to northbrook from the 'burbs is a bear.  but it's something you have to get used to if you want to work for them.
trying to get projects through the pipeline is very difficult and also trying to get individual teams on board with project changes is difficult.

if an employee's job at allstate involves customer assistance or support that job will be outsourced, probably to a call center or india. allstate has good benefits but the employee's cost of those benefits is too expensive.  there are also high co-pays when you visit even your in-plan physician.  onsite day care, oil changes, and dry cleaning are nice to have but are also too expensive.  there are no sick days; if... you have to miss work because of illness you take a vacation day.
looming layoffs. i was laid-off as well as about 2000 others and there's talk of more. it's a troubling time for the insurance co's.

extremely fractured culture, where different departments have entirely different attitudes and business norms.  in the past few years, every year there is a new initiative to remake the company, only to be forgotten and then overshadowed by next year's initiative.  sometime too political, promotions based not on experience or competency, but political gamesmanship.  and then they wonder why their having so many... problems!
if you are not a salesperson, there is no need to apply. if you are a salesperson, this could be a great opportunity, although rates and management leave something to be desired.

no employee type benefits like medical at this level - none - nada!  very few agents willing to refer the proper way, leading to cold-calling  everything 1099, so expenses besides office expenses; i.e. license registration, laptop, ce

lack of recent real world business experience from management; no new ideas on operating your business comes from management; you get more info regarding operating your business thru your own research.  management does not know how to motivate and inspire sales staff other than by fear of termination.

don't know where to start.  everything from parking to management sucks.  managers don't know which end is up and are always trying to one-up each other.  no career path, yet they micro-manage with quarterly """"checkpoints"""" (mini performance reviews & smackdowns).  complete sticklers about how & when you can take your vacation (24 hours notice is a must otherwise you get an """"occurance"""" on your record), calling in sick... is an """"occurance"""".  five occurances in a 12 month period gets you formally written up.  i worked in two different departments and they had totally different cultures.  hr was actually a lot of un, but it was awful.  no guidance, no training, no introductions, just """"here's your desk, do you job.""""  that being said, there were always meetings about nothing.  you'd sit in a meeting for 1-2 hours and come out not knowing anything new.  i finally left because i couldn't take the disorganization and chaos of it.
over worked!!! expectations are unrealistic. the typical adjuster should work 4-5 claims per day. 10-12per day was commonplace, yet expectations only got more stringent.

do more with less attitude.   if 5 employees are doing the job well perhaps one employee could replace all of them.   too much work to get done within normal working hours.  employees remain stressed.
pay is minimum compared to other pay levels in city.
promote work life balance, but don't always offer it.  promote tuition reimbursement, but don't want to allow the flexibility of schedule needed.  pay raises used to be good, now...not so much.
slow to market and implement change
there is a lot of favoritism.  the people that make it to the top are """"well liked"""" and it's not even hidden.

dead end job if looking for advancement opportunities. work within cublcle. up to 2% annual raise depending on performance. starting entry level claims is 33k annual. will take forever to make decent salary at that rate.

this was absolutely the worst work environment i could ever have imagined.  there were no real opportunities for growth and performance reviews and feedback were not objective.  managers lacks integrity and professionalism.  training is virtually nonexistent.  input from management is demoralizing, as opposed to constructive.  mentoring is only available for a select few.  the job is misrepresented as a """"financial... analyst"""" role.  """"financial systems analyst"""" may be a more appropriate title.  the focus of the department is on data mining, as opposed to analysis and interpretation.

cronyism is very much alive.  people have been here 30+ years and tend to stick to each other rather than give a newcomer much of a chance.  couple of senior tech folks like to think of themselves as super smart, super architects but their egos are much larger than their talent.  work was extremely boring but then, it is an insurance company and i was doing back office it at that, so maybe allstate isn't entirely at fault.  really, not much is expected out of you.  just clock-in, put your 8, and then go home.

company is still trying to figure out its mission  risk management is important, but not to the point where we make it so difficult for customers to buy things that they leave.  suitability and compliance should be a partner, not an obstacle.

there isn't much title differentiation among deeply skilled and experienced employees and those who have the same """"consultant"""" title but have notably lower levels of experience. this impacts the fair application of salary and status, the importance of which varies among employees. no stock purchase options or bonuses are available except for the few who are chosen.
access to training and educational benefits
time off was hard to get.  if you missed more than 4 times you were written up in one year.

i get the feeling that the salary is not very competitive outside of the company, and there are no bonuses other than a 401 match until you are a manager, which could be 10-15 years for when you start.

because of their conservative nature it causes them to struggle on the pricing side and while other companies are buying business allstate refuses to play that game. it means that you have to be able to sell service and unique products instead of price. this becomes difficult to do  under current situations. they continue to push the costs on the agency force without offering more competitive products or additional... compensation.

heavy workload. i don't think the leadership thinks realistically about how many people they should hire to help carry the workload. our goals were pretty stringent and (again) based on some unrealistic attainments. an e-mail was once forwarded that you should never expect anything over an """"meets expectations,"""" on your yearly review - this was sent as a joke but is more real than what you might think. if you are new..., never expect to get any part of the week of thanksgiving off (except for thanksgiving day) or any part of the week of christmas (except for christmas day).

no where to grow within an agency without owning an agency. the pricing is uncompetitive and the lack of effort to keep longterm customers is getting more and more frustrating. claims service could use a huge improvement. there have been major steps back in aspects of different department's organization and effectiveness. product management has their own agenda, so they are not willing to listen to agents input most of the time. software that is not ready for use and has lot's of bugs to fix is always a pain and slows down the work day. ridiculous compensation package for agents in regards to bonus playing such a large part of income. just have to play their petty game to make a buck.
having to learn the insurance business in such a short amount of time.
have to compete against internal hires for more interesting work. also, sometimes too sociable and too sports-centered. individuality sometimes needs to be concealed from the masses. too suburban.

higher rates due to better products.  lack of benefits  the pay is not so great as producers tend to just build the for the agent's pockets which is somewhat understandable as they take the majority of the risk.  leads are not provided by corporate.  credit check system is flawed.  lack of credit for sub producers and clerical staff that make agencies run.  have had problems with claims department per customers
very political, sales culture is under-developed, but moving in the right direction, company is top-heavy and has many non-essential layers of overhead.

with a small office, it can be overwhelming when there is much to be done.  if you cannot manage your time well, you will not have a great experience with the workload of this position.  also, the days can feel mundane and repetitive.  you have to find a way to make sure you are challenging yourself enough to overcome the feeling of being stuck in a routine.  with a small office, you do not have professional privacy....  if you are going to work as friends and colleagues, expect someone to know a little about your personal life and ongoings.

company’s focus has changed from customer friendly to foe, employee friendly to foe.  employees are expected to process multiple lines claims in ever decreasing increments of time, often sacrificing friendly conversations that kept customers renewing policies.   customer complaints are directed to partner sites where ill mannered employees inform customers they will have to wait longer.  the core values of the... company have changed along with the reorganization of long-term employees and anyone who expressed dissenting opinion became ineligible for another position within the company.
not too much room for growth when your close to the top unless you want to be management. the company is so large it is hard to get recognized unless you are on a big project.

some of the tasks within the analyst role seem monotonous. you seem to do the same things, at the same time of the month, every month. it personally was not my thing, but if you are looking for a corporate finance role than this place will be right for you.

work/life balance is terrible at times, lots of no-value added work, conservative work environment, seem to be lacking appropriate technology for being a fortune 100 company, lack of recognition for non-bonus level employees, don't encourage or reward advancing education, promotions seem to be based off of tenure rather than accomplishments, departments seem to work in silos.

where to begin? the food in the cafeteria is like airline food. you will find some of the realities of working in a corporate environment while working at allstate--tough to move around the company, merit increases small and very subjective, hiring freezes even though the company made a billion dollars in the year prior. working in a regulated industry can mean a lack of innovation.

recognitions sucks, favoritism or the scare of favoritism has just taken away advantages from some individuals and put it on others, or at least until someone complains about them, then it will just go to another group of individuals. i guess they think if you do it until someone complains it isn't favoritism huh? the pay sucks, but the benefits keep us there. plus management doesn't know what the hell they are... doing.

too much of a numbers driven company, some employees who have more time with company and have assisted management with supervisory positions were left hanging when it came time for promotion and gave several positions to people with less time and no experience. will not help adjusters if workload is too much, takes several managers to approve one day of down time. at the moment current management is seeking to use... more outside temp adjusters and transfer others to save on expenses.

if you are a visible minority or female, work at allstate. sorry, white males need not apply for promotions once they have been hired - its a glass ceiling once you turn 50 as a white male in the it area.  if you make waves, you'll be shown the door.

allstate seems to follow trends and not execute as well as other companies in its segment. management is entrenched and stale. upper management tends to come outside of the insurance business, and the bean counters seem to now run the company.

right now it is diffacult in the marketplace in california because we are no longer writing homeowners insurance through allstate, although we are brokering out a lot of business to other carriers. the competition is taking advantage of bad mouthing us in the assumption we are going financially insolvent which in fact is not the case. i have learned that every company has its big ups and big downs.
no benefits, incentives and you learn so much about insurance and claims you understand why people hate insurance salesman.

allstate is very bureaucratic and rigid in it’s procedures.  they see the achievement of repeatable processes only through inflexible regimentation.  there are no clear metrics to determine success but there is a general  understanding that there are problems.  high level financial evidence supports this so senior leadership is forcing improvements.  because of the lack of metrics the efforts targeted at making... these improvement are often ineffective and disruptive to the employees.

1) stripes very important.     2) too many people who just want to collect a paycheck.     3) politics is a way of life.   4) leaders  - some areas have great leades in place who understand the big picture, what it takes to get the job done and recognize their employees for their hard work and dedication.     other leaders are so caught up in trying to please their bosses and/or make their bonuses that they do not... care how the staff is impacted or if they are doing the right thing for the front line customers.

the benefits other than the vacation time are expensive for new employees. the longer you work there, allstate gives employees with more seniority better and better credits to offset the costs. the cooperation between areas is abysmal. the executives are in their own world. they value tenure and minorites above ideas.    within it, they just implemented a policy where most people are not assigned to teams anymore so... essentially they're working project to project and are therefore at risk. with this """"consulting model"""" which allstate says is new, why not get paid more and work for a real consulting company instead?
too much work too little pay
there's just the low pay.
no training, no guidance from seniors and supervisors
no good salary revision even after working hard for an year.
not every project offers best technologies and best environment. legacy projects have very less development. no room for improvement and learning

for now it is very difficult to get progression in the organization.

hard work, after a few years you get burned out (similar to consulting). due to nature of working on high level strategic projects, you don't usually see the outcome of your work immediately. strategic projects take a long time to implement.
boring and repetitive work, no innovation
new technologies are not yet adopted in most accounts. also, you might have to deal eith management politics very often.
you need take night shift during cut over or bill day
work life balance is not that good in some teams.
everything with manager.. even hr
large workforces command large problems  empowerment and work diversity takes time to occur
angry unprofessional people. no training. confusion amongst management. jealousy among workers. real nightmare.

no quality work involved. nobody knows what a defect is and how it should be measured and apply metrics defined under six sigma. focus is given only on product support but what about the qualitative metrics that should me made aware of ?
sweats employees.  poor advancement opportunities.

demanding, long work hours, uneven load spread

long hours, late night sometimes, hectic schedule during production time
tech stack little outdated, restrictive deployment environment
stability when business hick up, politics, too much in-professional people with good connections that get good jobs...

* workload saturation  * people leaving and remaining employees absorbing work load  * no concrete actions when it comes to trainings  * disregard for personal life times due to overtime  * it becomes extremely difficult to switch projects unless you are at the verge of unemployment

amdocs used to be great company but in last few years it has decreased its standard drastically.     1. cost cutting in food has been done and degraded the quantity and quality of food.  2. hikes used to be better before but now a days most of the people are getting single digit hike.  3. promotions are not given to old employees and company prefer to hire new people, that is degrading the quality.   4. management... is not fair and false promises are done to the employees.  5. travel department suck and you they bug you for each and every small thing.

have offshored many former talented and skilled workers jobs. this may endup hurting them way more financially in the future than the immediate financial savings by off shoring their jobs.

management is all israel controlled (expected?) and its easy for them to grow.   it doesn't matter if you are talented and put in a lot of efforts. you have to scream out to show your worth and wait very long to get recognized.

manila globe account:    1. say goodbye to your work/life balance.  2. say goodbye to your family during christmas, new year and other holidays as you will need to report onsite (beats the purpose of you having an internet connection at home). it sucks really.  3. say goodbye to your career goals and development. say what new technology? learning? nada. you won't get it here. they won't even invest in you like... certifications and classroom training. oh yes they have online training videos/tutorilas -believe me its crap.  4. you thought the company pays you well? give it sometime to sink in..and you will realize its not even close to how slave you are to them.  5. they maximize people..burnout is high.  6.  your slave job is not an 8am to 5pm schedule. you are oncall for 24/7. day-in and day-out. you will get calls as early as 2am in the morning. and calls even after your shift.  7. annual increase you say? -wow 35 usd and below enough for a 24/7 shift?  8. they ask so much of you to support the account even on a weekend. thus, you are spoc for a weekend. but beware its not considered ot until someone calls you..how crappy is that considering weekend is supposed to be your family day. worst thing is if the support call lasted for only 45 minutes..that is still not considered ot on a weekend.    9. only the """"yes man"""", """"sycophant"""", """"brownnose""""gets promoted. period. these department bosses/heads will get all the credit from your team's hardwork because they are the ones recognized/reporting to top management. you will literally settle for pennies.  10. hr handling is horrible. period.  11. only 13th month pay, no 14th. bonus is 94 usd -which gets nullified by tax.   12. so much more worst things to say..piece of advice get out of this account.

a) was an employee friendly with adequate compensation. not anymore .  may be you can get lucky if you are assigned to high value project or are a favorite (not based on ur work or knowledge or experience )      a) nepotism , cronyism , favoritism , red tapism rampant in this company. regardless what they say of labor laws, there is distinct discrimination of workers based on your country origins. israelis gets... preference in everything    b) hr policies differs from person to person, project to project and group to group.hr and immigration department-  they are the most arrogant and  not transparent at all. internally they have exception for their own  to grow themselves . not a good employee facing division.     c) amdocs ratio of management to actual worker are skewed upside down. more managers than software engineers atleast on onshore .     d) company was product company at one point of time and now lost direction with nor here or there.  management style is product based  (no bench policy etc) while client interaction and money is more on service based maintenance project.  and senior to mid management does not want to evolve.    e)most of the mid management are clueless ,inept. they just enjoy the position they are in where they cannot do any customer interaction or know their own product properly.  they will simply stay in limelight if going is good else put forward your face (experts and developers) if something not correct. they will not back you up nor fight for you as i guess they have to survive themselves.  worst spineless mid management.     f) employee welfare is least in the minds. no job security . instilled a sense of fear for all lower rungs and asking for more work else laid off.   no value of loyalty . you will thrown out at drop of a hat. even if there is a demand in other areas , they will drop you but not put you on the project which has requirement and hiring. really strange practice .     f) terrible work life balance if you happen to be in a project with more managers than worker.    g) dont care of your level of technical expertise or expereince. totally focussed on $ and that too not out in overall company revenues  but your own little subgroup .   i have been a high performer and acknowledged well by customer also , but at time of bonus , career growth and salary increment you would be left behind based on your immigration status / country of origin

the company management had failed in almost every way to keep this company relevant. today in this company there are a substantial amount of employees which work with technologies which were invented over 20 years ago. over the years amdocs has failed to renew itself and keep up to date with the market and thus its future is uncertain. the company is currently straggling and reducing costs and employees (especially... anywhere besides india), i guess they want to turn into tech mahindra rather than become more like google :)  another downside is that the company doesn't provide an adequate work/life balance.

amdocs is not doing well with its former top client, nor any of its us based accounts.  part of this is due to the shrinking margins in the telecom industry and amdocs applications becoming too expensive for that market.   however,  their own unique problems are what have amdocs circling the drain:    -amdocs offers arrogance instead of customer focus.    -amdocs has one focus ($) and neglects support of client’s core... businesses, while focusing solely on the current or next big $ project.   -nepotism and cronyism aren’t serving amdocs well.   -while executive management talks to clients, middle management sees little evidence of this due to an apparent lack of understanding of client requests.   -amdocs solutions tend to focus on what they (amdocs) want to do (technology), instead of how to solve the client’s problems with technology.   -amdocs is too technically focused. they undervalue and understaff every facet of support and communication required to implement and support the technology.   -amdocs is laying off long term and trusted us onsite employees in droves (50-95% of these onsite teams), leading to increasing instability for both amdocs and their clients.

little to no training upon hire (drinking from a fire hose and learn on the fly).  employees in the us sometimes feel like the ugly step children because major decision makers are located in israel, and the way they want things to operate does not always translate well in the us. input frequently sought, but rarely implemented, so sometimes feels like a token gesture.  many operations positions are being relocated... to india and latin america under the guise of consolidating shared services, or focus on emerging regions, but in reality it feels a lot like just  saving $$, so great, long-term employees in operations roles have been let go, losing more of the personal touch needed in hr and recruiting.  hr/ta budgets do not allow remote teams to get together enough to build relationships, engagement, and morale.  workload and expectations increasing with less and less support and people to do it.

cons:  - the biggest cons about amdocs - this organization will strip you off your talents and capabilities eventually morphing you into a lazy, careless and inept. your ambitions will be driven by onsite opportunities, bonuses, and free food. much like a government organization or a communist regime it doesn't matter how much harder or smarter you work, you will be paid same bonus/hike as your counterparts, making... you wonder what's the point of all these useless regressions.    - the company is hiring below average engineers from indian wholesale it companies like infosys, tcs, persistent, techm - compensating them below average salaries and making them work in r&d team! this is the biggest blunder a product-base company could commit. there is a reason companies like amazon, google, microsoft or even indian companies flipkart and ola are amongst the top of the food chain - they pay hefty salaries to their r&d employees, thus maintaining the quality of product with top notch innovation. if any concerned amdocs senior is reading this please raise your hiring bar, the new hiring was one of the main reason i personally left the organization.     - if you are fresher, kindly refrain from joining this organization, it neither works as a startup nor like an mnc, its a hotchpotch kind of setup with no definite direction or goal.remember - the learning isn't acquired from the work you do - nope. it comes from the people you work with and under, and amdocs is a complete let down in that department.    overall if you are looking for an organization to relax in pune, with no ambition, dreams, hopes, and zeal to learn, if you are and want to remain an average throughout your life, amdocs is the company for you.

where to start?  hr needs to be overhauled- not sure how they are allowed to hire 3 people of the same immediate family (mom, dad and son all working in the same location, husband and wife both working in same location (many examples), if you are isreali or russian this is the place for you! if not, be prepared to get chronically overworked and be underappreciated. you likely will have to work 10 years to ever get... promoted. many of the directors and senior leadership are incompetent but have """"connections"""" so despite their ineptness they somehow manage to maintain leadership positions and some of their husbands or ex-husband works there too!  also worth mentioning that some of the russian women are very inappropriate. some have been demoted only to have her next assignment be at an even higher level of responsibility. it has become a joke and soon the richardson location won't be able to retain top talent.     management in isreal needs to be aware of what's happening here- decisions are being made that are ultimately not in the best interest of the company and furthermore that are more short-term protections for management for their own positions and those close to them- at any cost.

unless you are a jewish male this is not the place for you. there are no opportunities for advancement, blacks and other minorities are all but forgotten. there are no blacks in any senior management positions and you could probably count on your fingers how many blacks there are in the company over all. woman do not fair any better as there is one woman in a senior management position and women are always the first to go.   raises and bonus' are given to the males of the company first and then whatever is left over is distributed to those lower on the food chain. you may average a 1% raise if you are lucky and a $2000 bonus which is double taxed so you will end up with nothing.  if you are thinking about working for amdocs run quickly in the other direction..

limited promotional career growth unless you work at the headquarters oversees. in fact, that's where all major decisions are made, resulting in a subset of the company population driving everything for all of the other global regions. tends to make the rest of the company feeling like they are on the outside looking in. considering most of the revenue is generated in the us, and in other countries, outside of the... hq location, it makes for a peculiar power imbalance. the promotions, rewards, and opportunities happen in one country, while the rest of the larger employee base operates as an outpost. the worst part is that employees get used to this unhealthy arrangement that they hardly notice that their empowerment has been zapped away from them.

amdocs' business model is based on acquisitions:     so if you work in a company that gets acquired by amdocs expect the following:    1-  you will slowly but surely have your culture erased and replaced by the amdocs culture. it's full of red tape and has many layers of bureaucracy. eta until full culture erase is 3 year.   2- it's an israeli based company so expect to have an irritating unprofessional army like... upper management structure.    3- only the flagship product will remain (reason for acquisition) all the other projects will be canned and the resources will be re-vectored to the flagship product.   4- if you're not in india, expect the r&d to slowly move to india. they will start by a small team in india and grow there.     this will lead to a stop to any creativity and/or new product development, and to a slow move to an indian heavy r&d organization through normal attrition.     i recommend to calmly start looking for another job once the acquisition happens, unless you're comfortable with long term stagnation and the occasional unprofessional contact with people from other business units.

the indian gl and managers before 10 years are now directors and vps. they have started the traditional indian way of cutting costs and not stopping the good people from going.  israeli management will innovate, have best practices, effective project management and programme management in order to reduce costs., but indian managers are taking that beauty of amdocs away.  today in amdocs, if you want to progress, you... should be able to impress your superiors. if you know this skill, then nothing else is required. onsites, promotions, favouritism and special facilities like leaving office at 4 pm are given to people who are 'ladlas' and 'ladlis' of the management. you will see the person who doesnt know anything promoted as manager, whereas person who is honestly working still gets an average grade.

the business model in hungary is to buy himself into business. then squezze people until they quit. after every 2 gone peope assign 50% to the project of a """"developer"""" in a low cost location.    amdocs in hungary is supporting billing sofware for telecommnication companies. the business was won from hp. at hp 30 people were doing this, the customer was satisfied. after amdocs took ower 10 people should have done the... same output in better quality and less time.    considering that:    - there is no hiring at all. if any, it is only in low cost location. (india)  - no investment in people or technology to facilitate work or quality. (10+ years old technology unchanged, no trainings, no documentation)  - it is expected from you to work a little harder often. unpaid extra hours + unpaid weekend work.   - after raising the problem to management, nothing ever changed.  - there are always issues with the reporting codes. co workers who are enterpreners often get paid late.  - customer is getting inpacient/angry for the drop of quality. which is always your fault.  ( from the 10 people above only 6 were working by the time i left...)    i think this business is going to terminate soon. don't join amdocs in hungary.

work is non technical , completely business, products already stable , only customization required,   need to multitask, tight deadlines on project basis, managers are weak , growth is slow , culture is not competitive enough for progressing as per your career.

work load- high  project timeline- aggressive, some are unrealistic  team force - insufficient members in a team   work life balance - not good. little time can be spent with family  percentage of burn out- high  management- still needs to work out in soft skills like leadership skills. still needs to adjust to culture of local.  communication- during issues people shout during discussions. its ok for foreigners... because its normal for them... but for locals its culture shock.  team work- not all teams work together to finish urgent task.   managers - there are still managers which are hard to work with and are more of slave drivers.  day off - there is a struggle to be able to get offs due to lack of members in the team  long vacation - there is low percentage of getting long vacations due to lack of members who can cover the task of others.  training- no formal training , they rely in peer to peer training and internal online training  transportation- no shuttles provided to employees   location of office is difficult to commute not near to affordable food establishments  work from home is prohibited even during weekdays  shifting schedule is not follow the sun  culture shock - high  health benefits - parents or other family members for single employees are not included to health card  many locals resign due to many factors like stress, work load, poor management... etc  non locals reassigned to other accounts due to stress and work load

very short duration onsite travels. usually one month.  lot of politics and bureaucracy in terms of promotions.  no work on latest technologies.  no technical growth.  no technical training. you will learn only from on job training.

- day by day reduction in facilities   - budget will keep cutting from your team so work load will increase eventually   - instead of giving benefits to best person in team manager will try to distribute it among all team equally so if you are real good at your work , you will not get satisfaction  - manager will give useless excuses while doing performance and rating, will will reflect in your salary and bonuses....  - you will have to work like hell once you are comfortable with your work.  - they can call you any time some people even got calls during their marriage   - weekends are not all yours , they can schedule you to work on any weekend depending on your profile  - managers are very impatient, they need updates all the time.
they do not reward based on merit.  those of us whose spouses work for amdocs are known as """"amdocs widows"""" for a reason.  there is absolutely no concern for work/family balance.

1. very poor hr policies. amdocs has a policy that there must be poor ratings given to some percentage of the employee base deserved or not.  2. when amdocs bought the company i was working for the first thing they did was give senior management stay bonuses. then everyone on the management team was demoted one level down.  3. the first thing amdocs said after the acquisition was 'these people make too much money... can't wait till we can take care of that'.

1. very bad management.  2. very poor indian style planning. the management includes weekends in their plan in all projects.  3. even though you will propose managers that  i would work 3 hours extra per day, 5 days please make my weeked free. they simply reject as due to poor indian management brain.  they are very greedy and always want more, doesn't matter how much you give them. as a result resource in project... goes 1 hrs in lunch .5 hrs in tea, 1 hours in pantry and 10 minutes walk from the 12 hr they report too. that's mandatory as anyway even you seriously work and give more in weekdays they are going to ask you to work in weekends without a single penny extra.  4. mangers don't have to work excpet chasing and calling employees day night.  5. very poor apprisal system. technically strong and weak people get same salary hike as a result every year technically strong people leave.  6. lot of buttering and favorism.

unchecked arrogance gives a few directors and higher the """"god complex"""" - a former director had been known to make people break down in meetings.    questionable professionalism - same director asked certain people to work on christmas eve (company holiday) because they were a certain religion (not christian) and their families wouldn't care.  i'm not in hr but shouldn't this type of behavior be frowned... upon?    sadly, he may not have even known better, probably because that's how he was treated moving up the ladder.   there are many managers who are technically brilliant but poor resource managers.    like many top-heavy companies, it's almost impossible to get a promotion - you'd have better luck leaving and coming back.    on the flip side of flexible hours is no concept of work-life balance.  of course, this depends entirely on your project and manager, but as a general company philosophy, having meetings at nights and on weekends is par for the course.

heavily international culture (israeli, indian) can make communication challenging; implementation-focused project workload; compensation peaks once you hit the upper limit of your band; annual bonus structure is heavily weighted to favor top performers and even then you rarely hit your target; lack of incentive to work harder than others; high workload means everyone is stretched very thin (quality can suffer)
- absolutely no work life balance, most of the projects are greatly understaffed so you are asked to put a lot of extra hours

higher management is worst  they have good market base, but they dont know how to take advantage of it...they are not sure even if they can retain it..  very high attrition rate..  no one currently present in the company has good knowledge of the product which they are selling in the market.  recruitment quality has gone done during the recent times..
less opportunity for r&d and innovations
very poor quality of work they do;  they do not care of the quality  poor middle management  poor work/life balance

lack of care, disrespect to employees, told to find other work if you don't like it, cattiness that never gets addressed, no raises, think inside the box, do as i say even if it doesn't return good results

you need to work like anything. seems like you dont have a right to a personal life outside this company.    no proper documentation.management would put you in a new field expecting you to know everything beforehand on your own.

the compensation growth was very much impressive a few years ago. but after the recession, the company decreased the growth % drastically to single digits. but now the company is looking to make amends to its policies to attract newer work force. believe me, dox can definitely improve

- you will not get a raise/promotion in the first 18 months  - after that raises/promotions are very rare  - *israley* management is really poor: a lot of incompetent people """"on the bridge"""" (phone call) from home while you are on the battlefield working 18 hours/day to meet an impossible deadline  - they virtually enslave poor third-world guys from cyprus/india  - bonuses are 1-2% of your salary (and it is good!)
- lower pay  - not enough opportunity for growth  - no overtime pay  - growth based strictly on seniority  - bad work-life balance
low remuneration and benefits  fewer opportunities for personal growth (especially technical)  unequal treatment between nationalities  moderate quality of product customization development

no respect for employees at all.  layoffs continually being threatened.  management doesn't care about work/life balance.  career dead end.  all they care about is how many overtime hours you put in and not pay you for them.
before your job is off-shored you get to train your counterpart and are expected to work 7 day weeks to meet an impossible deadline with the illusion you may keep your job

extremely limited growth opportunities at current location. strong balance sheet does not necessarily translate to job stability, layoffs have been the norm, good financial year or bad. sr mgmt, hr, etc not employee friendly at all, though they keep on feeding the """"employees are our biggest asset"""" spiel. middle management, though has a lot of good people, get screwed by the the typical """"responsibility without... authority"""" problem.

not much onsite opportunities. the promotions are strictly based on number of years of exp. if you are capable enough they will make you work as a senior position but you will get promoted only when you complete the required years.
politics, politics, politics.  competition between different divisions and departments.  aggressive nature of much of the communication.  lack of promotion opportunities.
senior management manages to the stock price. they work their people hard, demanding 50 hour work weeks. they also give significant preference to israeli vendors.
too much  work with a little of recognition. a lot of politics.  very often projects are performed in the mode of  'crisis mitigation'.
management ignores personal life completely, a lot of requests to work extra time / weekends without any compensation, company reacts to market changes very slowly

the way they still treat the employees.     senior management has no problem with lying and forcing the manager to ask preloaded questions at all-hands and also has no problem ending these meeting when faced with difficult questions in order to not answer them.    went from 4 large builds to 2 large buildings to 2 smaller buildings to 1 building to 1/2 a floor.

your advancement at this company is completely based on connecting with and impressing senior management. it also helps to be israeli. there is no accountability for managers actually doing performance reviews and if they do its a joke. there is very little strategic planning so most of your time will be spent running from crisis to crisis. some managers are better than others though.
management plays a lot of favoritism.

there is no concept of work life balance, every so often there will be a push by management towards this, but it lasts only until the next crisis.  at my location they constantly cut the work force down and add new projects onto already overworked people. i have been involved in several contracts and can state without a doubt that although they will build resources into the cost to the customer rarely are those... actually fulfilled to the teams.  run...don't walk to the next opportunity!
not creative environment. incompetent management. top-down micromanagement. not fair promotions.

hours are long  there is not a work life balance as you can be involved in calls as early as 6 am and as late as 11 pm.  i have seen many fellow colleagues work until 3 in the morning to get work completed.  time line are at times unrealistic and deliverables from israel are at time lacking

very long work hours.  occasionally inflexible policies made from """"on high"""" that have unintended consequences because of insufficient investigation about the actual problem.  some coworkers can be difficult to work with because of cultural differences and expectations.

management does not appreciate your work and will make you stay up all night to to do a """"really important"""" task. amdocs gives you a good idea of what not to do on a project. there are a few good managers that will really help you with your career but most do not care at all so at the end of the day, it doesn't matter.

acd partners with amdocs corporate development teams. depending on who won the project, the project is either owned by the consulting division or by corporate business unit. this can lead to alot of internal power struggles, in addition, acd employees are treated as staff augs rather than true consultants.

the way they treat their employees. they don't seem to have a problem with telling lies to all the employees to justify the reason. (i.e. we value all you long term employees, right before they get laid off for not fitting the new business model). the business model of, you are over paid and i can hire 10 people in india based on your salary. they only care about the cost per employee, not the results.

poor communication skills of the middle/senior management team (the exception are among the managers with good to fluent english and good knowledge of the north american culture) - this is explained as the majority of the managers are coming from technical roles and minimal to none management training or knowledge. management brings a lot of stress into the daily routine as if today is the end of the world. among... the many managers i've worked only one stood out from the crowd.

promotion based on a chance rather then on actual performance. you can be promoted because someone left, got fired, etc, it is not related to how exactly you perform on a daily basis, rather then on a chance.
technically you may not learn much
the culture is truly terrible.  don't expect  -management to back you up  -professional training  -new employee training  -timely managment review  -career mobility
respect for colleagues is dismal, people often feel that responsibility is a burden. incompetent managers.

mediocre benefits and compensation level relative to the amount of work demanded. from director level and up, advancement is purely political and is completely unrelated to talent, skill or performance. there are many upper management positions currently filled by """"deadwood"""" - people who do absolutely nothing but get paid a high salary. management is actually supporting a culture of secrecy and opaqueness in internal communications.

there is a lot of bureaucracy. israel tries to run every project. there are policies which show a fundamental lack of understanding about statistics like forced bell curves in performance reviews. management likes to pride itself on its open door policy, but in fact, if you openly speak out or express disapproval or disagreement with business practices, expect to be reprimanded. during company meetings, we're often told how wonderful and bright the future is. but when it comes time for a raise or a bonus, we're told how grim things are and how amdocs cannot afford to reward its hard working, loyal associates. they think they own you and feel like they have a right to call you on vacation, at night, in the middle of the night, on weekends.
excessive bureacracy for every employee level, but worse the lower you go; complete lack of trust in empoyees
lack of career growth opportunities
communication, employee morale, respect, benefits
many layers of hierarchy; for some travel is too taxing
there is a bias towards israelis
poor salary, promotions are made not on good criterias, weak organisation and professionalism

3 downsides of working @ amdocs  1. if you work in the product management or marketing fields, then beware: one look at the annual report (which i recommend you download and read if you're considering a job here) will tell you that we are a very service centric company. even though we are pushing hard to get our product heritage to market, a vast majority of our revenue comes from customized solutions, and managed... services deals. this makes it very difficult to effectively manage your product in such a service centric environment. because amdocs has a track record of always completing a project (amdocs does most of its implementations), this can de-stabilize product roadmap activities as r&d resources get recommitted to making our customers complex implementations successful. you will have to be able to juggle these priorities, as firedrills will happen. on the other hand, we are known for our successful implementations (unlike an infamous competitor of ours... ;0)  2. bi-polarization  a large part of amdocs' senior management team is based in israel. this creates almost a nucleus of managerial power. this also sometimes creates a sense of disconnect with the heart of the organization. this can affect some more than others. i suspect that our colleagues based in australia, india, or south africa, or even latam feel this more than the european and north american offices. you will have to be prepared to travel frequently to israel to keep your visibility going, and make sure that you can gain traction with your market and product initiatives. the managerial responsibilities are globalizing gradually, so there is signs of improvement here.
there are no cons to working for american fidelity.  fantastic company for employees who are willing to work smart and keep balance in their lives.
lots of work  overtime   not good work life balance

major structural flaws that management has no interest in changing. the company markets the account manager position as unbiased benefits consultant to the school districts. however solutions you recommend need to include af products if you want to proceed.  overall the position and company are a tragedy, there is a real need for benefits education in the school system. unfortunately the model they use just funnels... money back to the company's owner bill cameron. who happens to be the  103rd richest person in the world.

if you have any skills or talents what so ever, stay clear.  the management here is pretty bad, anything new or different, they'll shoot it down.  most people here is with the company 5+ years.  they are comfortable with what they do and don't want to change.
way too much travel depending on where you live. i traveled probably 80% and the demanded more. on top of that the work load is insane. this isn’t a long term career option in this state.

the presentation to the sales team is that a level playing field exists, and it doesn’t take long for you to realize that this is not the case.  sales quotas increase, and opportunities stay level or decrease depending on who the managers are close with.
management biased - management plays favorites

this company is a myriad of law suits waiting to happen.  first hiring is not based on talent, ability, or qualifications but rather the good ole boy network.  minorities can apply got don't get your hopes up and they people they do hire are not qualified to do the job.  as with the hiring, minorities will struggled here, not that the superiority is outright or blatant but subdued and assumed.  in both hiring and... promotional opportunities the good ole boy network trumps everything else.  management is erratic and quotas are based on weather they want you to remain with the company or terminated.  they will smile and play nice to you directly then stab you in the back when you are not looking. this is not the company for you if hiring and promotion based on talent, performance, and merit is important to you.
there are really no disadvantages in working at american fidelity
hiring process takes some time, but worth the wait.  company keeps growing which is good, but keeps me busy.
their can be travel but the company pays for everything.
experiencing some of the fear that comes with more automation.

in an environment that changes so much it would be nice for more preparation. we get so many junk emails on a daily basis it’s hard to keep up with what’s important.   management isn’t on the same board. different rules from one to the next.   some departments are extremely unorganized which makes for a poor customer experience.   poor communication between departments which makes it confusing for the customer.  too many different departments. if a customer has a cancer policy, texas life, flex account and annuity and they want to make a payment and need help submitting a claim that could be potentially 5 different people they end up talking to. after 6 months of being a permanent representative i feel like each person should be crossed trained on an additional product and that should continue every 6 months with a refresher course offered as well.   very selective in hiring process. i’ve referred 10, 8 of which have had interviews and have not been hired. all of which have very similar backgrounds to me and i was hired. the application process is difficult as well if you don’t know someone who works for the company.   the quality scoring process is very uptight for a company that’s so fun and laid back.
food selection at the on-site cafeteria is not great.  think california health plate out the wazoo.
work overload, but other than that i have no complaints
management involvement, quota set-up, training
none really. maybe too many meetings? but i think that's a product of the collaborative like, inclusive work environment. it's a tough balance, i'm sure.
slow upward mobility. the company has been around a long time, attracts top talent and the talent stays and also grows conservatively. this means that upward mobility is slow.

team lead bullies good reliable workers out of their positions by firing them or making them pursue other job opportunities outside of the company. with this comes a lack of good training due to all the people who retained the knowledge being gone. the company does not look into the loss of good employees and continues to allow team lead to effect these things.
travel can be extensive at times but i know this is something the company is working to try to fix.
some older staff causing roadblocks and not understanding many of the technology changes and progression.  could use an update to some processes and a bit more understanding to change.

bonus structure has made some employees feel a sense of entitlement.  aging workforce is also difficult to coach toward technology shifts.  also, the annual review and check in processes are tedious and i don't feel i gain insight from them.

unfortunately, there are a number of incompetent and just plain bad supervisors who sucked the life and the ability to do a competent job right out of their employees, and hr always sides with the supervisor over the employee. it's very sad that employees with years of service and excellent reviews can be let go because a supervisor takes a personal dislike to them.

understaffed, high turn over, and micromanagement. for a company that wants us to have work/life balance  it is hard to make time when we are always forced  to do mandatory overtime when things get busy.which is always. when a depsrtment can't pull any staff to work emails and force  5-7 hours of overtime a week  there is no time for anything else.

i had high hopes when i started as an account manager for afa.  everything at first appeared to be wonderful with great co workers etc.  however, the honeymoon quickly wore off and the ugly bride underneath came to light very quickly.  the state manager micromanaged every aspect of your day.  you never knew from one day to the next where you were going to be as she was so inept at management that she could not keep... the calendar straight.  favoritism towards a few senior reps was very apparent including colluding against some of the newer reps who were outselling the more senior reps.  the greatest issue i had with this company was the lack of ethics.  i personally witnessed my state manager forge teacher signatures and recommend products that were not appropriate.  i believe a majority of their account managers failed their securities license at least once if not multiple times yet these are the same reps meeting with the teachers and helping them with their retirements.  if you can't pass the series 6 and 63 the first time then you have no business handling anyone's investments.  it's not a difficult test.  so, if you're considering employment at afa, especially as an account manager, my advice is to turn around.  it's not worth it.  you will suffer.  your family will suffer.  it's simply not worth it.
low salary because so much emphasis on the bonus.  a lot of micromanaging at times. meetings can be monotonous at times.
it is commission based poorly

high stress, low recognition, inconsistent management practices, old school management thinking, undervalued departments, politics are atrocious across the organization,  security division is poison, prefers blocking roads versus protected escort, management prefers big ideas and vision over practicality and realistic productivity (for example - open, collaborative workspace/floor for a division spent mostly on... focus work daily)

the management is terrible.  they discriminate for all kinds of reasons.  however, if you've had a military background then this is the place for you.  if you've never served in any branch of the military they will try to make you quite.  if you are tough enough to make it through the gauntlet then they will come up with excuses to fire you!

it's hard to move up in the company and the do not promote from within.  they do not value the employee.  they used to be a family oriented company but bill cameron stepped down and dave carpentar took over and family no longer mattered!

so, just about everyone says travel here, and i think that is fully and completely overblown. is travel involved? yes. but most days, in ohio at least, i am no more than 1.5 hours from home, and i usually get home before my wife does from her 8-5 job. plus, they ask you to travel, they don't tell you to. we have some people in ohio all the time because they want to, and we have some people who ask not to travel so... much, and they don't! otherwise, this job is what you make it. some parts of the year (summer) can be slow, but with a little foresight and organization, you can make those times productive as well. honestly, most negatives i've seen have been written by people who may not have been successful and are blaming the company. i will suggest that, if you can't succeed in this job, it's entirely on you.

i would politely but immediately pass on this opportunity. they pay a paltry salary and only have two times through the year to make any real money. marching toward benefit enrollment effective dates on 1-1 and 7-1. the rest of the year you will be scratching to make quota with your manager riding your back every step of the way and this is in a developed territory. if you are in an undeveloped or sparsely populated... territory forget it you cannot make quota. the turnover is so high that district managers are constantly on the chopping block for not being able to """"hire right"""" or keep employees. managements sales line is """"we want this to be your last job"""" they developed this to explain away the high turnover. when you interview you will notice they sell you the opportunity instead of you selling your self to them. almost like mlm. weird. there's a reason for this.
the company owner is being sued for fraud in tulsa.
travel.  although i am putting htis down as a """"con"""", this comes with any high income producing position that you find, and the company is very upfront about the expectations for it.
the only downside would be the amount of travel, but that was very clearly communicated to me early on, and the company covers all of my travel expenses.
travel - this is explained at all the interviews but make sure you tell your family about the time away

the 401k pension and medical insurance could be a little better, however, they're still adequate.  as long as you're a hard worker, able to quickly innovate, and get along with everyone, you'll do fine here!
very conservative culture some of the employees need to lighting up some.
legacy systems makes progressive change difficult due to expense.  the current move has taken a ton of time but will be awesome when it's all done.
significant travel for sales positions (although fully paid for by afa)  need to develop better online service tools for customers  varying degree of proficiency for managers

there are tons of projects to get done, and despite the formation of a committee that is supposed to prioritize projects, it can still feel like there is no strategy.  it can be easy to get lost in all the work that needs to be done in order to feel like you're making a solid contribution towards a common goal.

i was with american fidelity for almost 2 years.    micro-management, preferential treatment of some, travel (by travel i mean you are in your car on the interstate and staying at the hampton inn), high turnover, low flexibility for time-off. if you have small children and want to be around them then this job is not for you.    i was sent to job-shadow a veteran account manager my second week on the job and he quit... on friday of that week. i should have seen the writing on the wall. as soon as i was licensed i was thrown into an enrollment and learned on the job. i spent 6 weeks in this account only to have the same account terminate their contract with american fidelity just a few months after this, the primary reason being turnover of account mangers. this put me in a constant sales deficit that i was not able to overcome.    (*if a policy lapses within 13 months after it is issued then you have to pay back the commission to american fidelity, plus that amount comes off of your production for the year.)    i was already struggling with not having enough accounts to work in, thus limiting my production/sales, and then having to payback a large amount from every paycheck landed me on probation.     at one point in my career my state manager told me that i was the best account manager he had ever seen one-on-one with the client. i was able to connect on a level that went far beyond just trying to sell someone insurance. i truly enjoyed the one-on-one aspects of my job, but the constant pressure to meet sales quotas and being continually not at-quota put pressure on me as an account manager to sell customers anything and everything, not just what they needed.    my state manager also played favorites selecting other account managers to work in new accounts and better schools while i was often sent to the bus garages and historically lower yielding accounts.     american fidelity has the history of being a great place to work but recently with high turnover and mediocre middle management this has become not even a good place to work.  bottom line: if you have other options for a paycheck take them. if you are desperate for a job then you you have to do what you have to do.    a district manager once tried to sell me on the fact that being away from home made his time at home """"special"""".  this same dm went on to tell me later about how his wife of 20+ years packed up everything and moved out while he was away on business. so much for """"special"""".
no cons as of yet.  i've sat here, trying to think of something negative to say, and i honestly can't think of anything.

high turnover in sales resulting in constant reassignment of accounts and frustrated employers who suffer poor service from the lack of continuity.    very long hours, often arriving home on fridays after 10 pm, then leaving sunday again.    repetitive sales reporting and other administration burdens that seem unnecessary.    do not count on bad weather being a good reason to reschedule an enrollment or business trip....    bad reputation in some regions creating a significant barrier for success.

american fidelity loves to tout their """"salaried"""" account reps. don't let this fool you. it is a very strict quota/commissioned based job. local management doesn't hesitate to throw new account reps under the bus for their mismanagement of accounts/blatant incompetence. new account reps are promised a local territory when in actuality you will be driving 5+ hours away on a regular basis. quotas are unreasonable.... management constantly threatens you with termination if sales goals aren't reached.

my manager was a major gossip  poor opportunities for money and advancement  too many accounts to manage and still give excellent service.  good old boy network  not woman friendly  senior level executives are only concerned about themselves

no say or control with your projects. examples -- 1: consultants they hire become your boss and if they don't like you for any reason they will have your boss push you to quit or they will firer you. 2: the users controls what they want to implement then tells isd to make it happen, they do this without consulting with the people that have the knowledge of what can be done.
a lot of driving and could be some overnight travel.
while minimal turnover and a """"small company feel"""" are great attributes, they do add to the feeling that employees have no way to move up within the organization.
