when i started about 10 years ago, there was an atmosphere that the company cared for the employees that did a good job.  those that didn't meet minimum standards didn't last long, and those that excelled were compensated well.  the re were frequent small perks that didn't cost hte company much, but still let the worker bees know that they were appreciated - things like fermentation seminars, ocassional free breakfasts, crhistmas parties, that sort of thing.  but there hasn't been any of those things for at least four years now.    couple that with multiple rounds of layoffs, expanded usage of contract workers (at a year or two a a time), and there's no wonder that the morale across the company has been falling.  though """"shareholder value"""" has been increasing for the last year and a half, the consensus among employees is that the board and ceo are doing their best to pump up hte stock price so that they can make a mint in the short term, at the expense both of patients and us hourly employees.

lip service to values that are not followed in practice e.g. work-life balance, ethical competitiion, success via merit.   management is extremely thin-skinned and brooks no 'disconfirming information' that goes counter to financial marching orders.   overly aggressive and unrealistic outsourcing is going to cause major pipeline delays and financial damage.

salary re-leveling, politics, and uncertainty of future due to biotech shakeup and internal business model change.  limited communication causes a chaotic environment with individuals blaming others. very sad to see a """"every man for themselves"""" type of environment versus fostering a great opportunity to network with peers internally.

beware of start and stop of major contruction sites and remote site developement.  prone to significant lay-offs.  the company seems to be transitioning away from in-house manufacturing to contract manufacturing.  bogged down with over compliance.
- politics have increased  - spend way too much energy/resources on keeping certain executives happy (quiet) instead of doing more important work

the current executive staff are destroying the company. morale is incredibly low. there is little contingency planning for the massive reorganization that is in process, and most current employees do not view the changes as being for the better.   last year there were no raises for mid career folks and above. this is likely to continue into next year. salaries are considered overinflated. so, there have been slow... cuts to benefits that are likely to continue. great folks have worked for over 10 years with no hope of a promotion in sight. this leads to entire departmental groups of people skilled enough for promotion. so many in a pool like that leads to backstabbing and cut corners.   overspending on poor decisions and corporate perks continues unhindered despite cuts to staff.  additionally, there are so many administrative layers that one spends more time on administrative stuff than real science.   most who are smart are making plans to move on.
culture, poor leadership at the director and executive director levels,
promotions and internation explansion not us based
going through major transition in therapeutic areas
lack of decision making, very ambiguous environment.
work life balance; low morale & productivity; changing uncertain environment including pending lay-off and restructuring are affecting the culture and values of the amgen of old.
too top heavy. organization has changed a lot and lot of work load.
no benefits, no days off no paid sick days, all ftes feel like they have some sort of power over you
amgen has changed from a science based company centered in values and development to a another big pharma driven only by finances.

decision making has too many layers but management is looking to peel the """"layers of mgmt"""" in this restructuring effort.  it will make position the company for success given it's promising pipeline.
working with amgen counterparts and adopt their cya culture.

also in a list format: top-heavy company, sometimes risk-adverse, sometimes slow to make decisions (which is typically endemic in a larger corporation), competitive environment, relatively weak career development opportunities, and last but certainly not least the current reduction-in-force announcement.

the company is too top heavy- so many vps.   right now, the emphasis is bottom line for the shareholders and not so much for the employees.  communication is not a priority from the top down, and it seems the rumor mill is rife.
-slow decision making  -too many under-qualified, over-paid executive directors and vps... many from early amgen and need to move on as they limit progress
us opportunities shrinking.  more and more of the us operations are being reduced or relocated.
non innovative, tough to push projects through that add value, poor accountability
work life balance, leadership, direction of company is shaky right now for sustainable employment.
thousand oaks is a slow city that sleeps by 9pm. if you want a late night dinner, you will have very few options.

micro management and top heavy.  too many evps/directors to name.  little to no professional growth possible anymore.  too much bureaucracy, decision making heads, no growth and constant looking over your back
lack of leadership (across functions), highly political/bureaucratic, lack of trust among teams and co-workers, limited growth opportunities and low morale.
the culture is intense, and that is no understatement.  the hierarchy is like no other within the industry, very much a top down organization focused on the bottom line.

near constant reorganization of departments gives a sense that leadership cannot make clear decisions. benefits have waned over the last several years. morale has been in the basement. recent efforts to restructure have dragged on for nearly a year with no action. bench scientists and other technical workers are steadily being replaced by contract workers.
change, change and a lot more changes on top of each other without regard to impact on staff morale, sustainability, or work-life balance. very limited promotion opportunities.
people insensitivity - little to no investment in human capital of any substance.  very hierarchical
aggressive micro managing senior management. no vision other than satisfy shareholders. and by the way that doesn't include patients no matter what they say.
decision making and risk analysis
the company has a global manufacturing focus so the amount of production opportunities in the us has dramatically declined over the past few years.
the yes man rules here. feedback is welcomed just as long as it is aligned with what the boss wants to hear. performance not equitable across organization. too many distractions.
can be very slow to make key decisions, started to really down size or """"reaching amgen's full potential"""" as they call it, 3 lay- off's in 5 years at the colorado site operations,
company has changed for the worse over the past several years
big organization where sometimes the right hand doesn't know what the left is doing.  corporate emphasis on improving decision-making still has a way to go.  too many meetings.
constant restructuring over last several years. capital investments that don't make sense, go over budget and are late.

no room for movement at all. must play the politics game and be good at it cuz there are people that can outwit you. hr services are for managers only and no internal movement process in place. stuck forever unless you leave. also, the more cuts they do, the worse it gets for you. 6 days a week working, calling all hours of the night, this leads to no time with family/marriage life or in regard to your health.
can be high stress. very competitive. very corporate
the company has undergone several reductions in force lately and this is beginning to impact the morale of the company.

politically challenging. difficult upward mobility, especially if you are a senior manager. constantly re-organizing it makes it difficult to focus and execute on top initiatives. excessive red tape, fighting through hoops to get anything accomplished. top down directives minimizes creativity.

the management is taught to be tyrannical, disconnected from their employees, and extremely uncaring.  i've never worked for worse, and i've been working for corporate america for 20+ years.  they are known for huge layoffs, they don't hire older people and those rare individuals that are there have been there for a long time and end up laid off.  finally the executive management fosters and environment of... egotistical, self-centered, driven to succeed at all costs individuals.
little gets accomplished/changes, little room to learn new things or participate in projects your interested int.
lack of telecommuting opportunities, time off policy,
very slow in making decision.
downsizing so good luck getting a job there. also, many of the managers actually mange very differently from each other and have varying expectations.

if you're not chinese, you'll be treated slightly better than a slave.  there are no rules, no gcp, no adherence to standards, no direction, no learning from mistakes made, no best practices. this is a free-for-all with a bunch of leaders that have not been held accountable.  hr is useless and in on the free-for-all calling shots from who gets interviews to who gets promoted without discussions with those who will... be or have been working with the personnel. no personal growth plans, no organizational structures, senior leaders don't communicate, or when they do they confuse rather than clarify issues.
company has lots of layoffs; little regard for base staff
there was a reorganization once and people didn't like it.
lack of career development, and poor decision making ability of management
amgen faces organizational challenges common to many large companies.  decision making can be slow, compounded by the many layers of management, committees, and approval processes in place.
limited upward mobility in canada, expectation that staff who really want to grow will move to california head office.

the benefits make it hard to leave. they're known as the """"golden handcuffs."""" thousand oaks is a miserable town to live in, unless you are ready to have your white picket fence and 2.5 kids. then it's a great town to live in.

excessive metrics of every function (analysis paralysis) no longer a nimble organization. uninspiring management, filled with good old boy politics, promotion of incompetent or mis-casts proteges. promotions based on who you know, not talent. so many really talented, sharp people have made a mass exodus from the organization due to the politics, poor leadership and inability to move their career forward. the dna of... the company and what it once had as value in the talent pool has evaporated. most of field sales force are new or less than three years tenure. you'll find a lot of people """"hanging on"""" to keep benefits and retirement options or people that came over for the amgen they heard of but no longer exist.
really top-management heavy, sending all manufacturing offshore or to contract manufacturers. hard to move up anymore.
lots of recent """"displaced reps""""... long term employment looks grim.
ever changing priorities make it difficult to become an expert when
limited opportunity for growth, at least in co as they have been ramping down production there for the last number of years. 24/7 facilities.
over 50% of the workforce is contract

poor life-cycle management strategies have led to cut backs and tension among those who work at amgen. many times, senior executives are unable to disclose information about company initiatives that may directly effect middle management and their staff. promotions and career advancement is difficult.
large company red tape, multiple locations
very demanding, less opportunity to move up
totally risk adverse and leads to some crazy decision making. decision making at senior level at senior level suspect
work schedules can be tough for families  difficult to move within the company
due to company's size, getting to be more bureaucratic, less flexible and delayed decision making
less growth opportunity, cutting r&d budget

still struggling to get internal research right-sized  numerous acquisitions in past 12 years have created numerous small site challenges  will continue to outsource to contain costs - disruptive no matter how well done
profoundly affected by obamacare.  job security seems less stable.
poor management, unethical and unecessary spending.  there are still many 'old timers' who do nothing!

company has financial results dependent on just a few products protected by patents, which will eventually expire. new blockbuster drugs are not that easy to come up with anymore. as a result of the current patent protection, company struggles with a very relaxed approach to business.
short therm strategy, prize big mistakes
long hours and many meetings. power point communication.
challenges that come with a larger size organization...like innovation/ideas taking longer to get off the ground and get implemented.
glacial trying to get a new project approved or a capex purchase made. even though once its doneit can be done on an almost unlimited scale the approval process is too long.
competitive, sometimes cut-throat culture- sometimes very stressful.  limited opportunities for advancement.   limited forgiveness for mistakes.

once you're in the door, career growth is slow as most hiring occurs from outside to take advantage of the weak economny.  amgen is also the most generous company in the area and there are not many external opportunities that match their benefits and compensation.  if you want to grow your career and match your total compensation, expect to relocate.
senior management gets more money while those doing the work (director and down) are getting less and less every year.  keep taking away the little things.  lack of development opportunities.
overly political, if you aren't """"in"""" with the managers you will be pushed around and pushed out. hr is useless and in no ways supports the working class.
career growth is limited and there are not many pharma companies in the neighbourhood
old ceo only cared about his compensation.

lots of corporate politics, some people enjoy this stuff i guess, i can't stand it  not much interesting work in is, just following procedures to the letter. again, some people like this, so if you do, then this would be a pro
it's the only big company in the area, so you are isolated a bit.
laying off ftes almost every other month in the past 6 months that i am aware of, and the company hires contractors for those positions.

sometimes you get stuck working in areas that aren't exactly your first choice and sometimes its hard to get out of that position. sometimes people are moved around to different groups and never get a good amount of experience in any one area due to the constant moving that is needed by the business.
somewhat difficult to move upwards as the company has a very flat organizational chart.
very hard to move up in company.  company thinks employees should do many lateral moves before trying to move up.

amgen has steadily been outsourcing every possible function within the company and contingent workers are not treated with the same regard as full time employees. even staff having transitioned to cw positions are suddenly """"less than"""" and amgen is sure to make sure that cw's are aware of their status. the recent leadership changes have created a cutthroat corporation, focused only on the bottom dollar rather than a... company that has a genuine concern for staff.
as a large company, amgen has many of the trappings of size (e.g. slower decision making, heirarchy, work process complexities).
the acquisition was painful and they missed out on some good opportunities to make it better. i was utterly unimpressed with their hr team.

last few years mgmt has been heavy-handed with cost-cutting. people with 10-15 years tenure were let go with a few hours notice.  no visibility to mgmt decision-making.  bottom-line is the stock price. so watch your back and keep a step-ahead of layoffs.
opportunities for advancement are limited,  work life balance is not encouraged.  values are left by wayside due to continued attrition and layoffs and workloads increasing 2 or 3 fold.

- senior executives don't seem to understand the beautiful list of company values  - the mission statement seems only an advertising but nothing behind  - don't seems to behave socially responsible but only care about topping up the share value at what ever the cost with no attention to company values   - hr department in zug  is very inefficient and nothing is moving in time
no real growth. very intense environment and company lacks innovation.

the company has lost its way, and no longer relies on the original values that made it successful.  lack of work-life balance.    limited career development opportunities.  leadership decision making is questionable and self-serving.
no work-life balance  corporate culture shift from the early days to today has caused the company to become more bureaucratic and less team oriented  it is viewed as a commodity
not much career growth at my level
never-ending reorganizations, create uncertain environment

quick to outsource groups without looking at individual contributors  too much focus on lean and fast cost savings  executive leadership depends too heavily on gss to make decisions on outsourcing work
poor work life balance. staff work under a lot of pressure

right hand does not know what left hand is doing  too much greed and too much 'marketing' to the masses to give us that focus is more than just about profit: who cares about the patients when we milk them to the tune of billions yearly?
oppressive work environment, conformance valued more than innovation.
in a bid to reduce costs they made a huge mistake by outsourcing it and now are trying to bring it back in house.  the cio had to fall on his sword and leave as a result.  the current ceo needs to go
not a lot of professional growth opportunities.
expected to work hard and to do more than your job role, work life balance isnt as flexable as it could be.

i got laid off, totally blindsided and i feel this was due to poor management of projects and constent turn over.  working for a big compnay has its cons and amgen displays all of them. too many cooks in the kitchen and typical poor business practices.  it is a shame because the company used to be one of the best in the area.
too big, slow to respond to changes
slow growth, no focus on career growth

as an employee at a remote site, it's disheartening to see people leave the site and not be replaced; mgt seems to be giving the message that they're reluctant to increase head count at the site.  additionally, despite their annual goal to """"develop our people"""", people are leaving because of the """"we only promote based on business need""""; it's as though the company is trying to have it both ways (talented,... walk-on-water employees who remain at the same employment grade and salary), and people aren't buying it.
lack of promotions, corporate america
you may get undersold when authority under values you at all. leadership may or may not be competent with your job.
very flat company structure so can be difficult to move up levels which can be challenging when you are looking to make a step up
thousand oaks site is too isolated.  no other biotech companies in the vicinity.  lack of strong solid leadership.
too many telecons, databases, time zone difference generally is not taken into account when scheduling trainings, meetings, tc's, poor internal communications
very slow moving, too much oversight, over employed so little ability to get promoted or make lateral moves, need too much buy in for every decision.
high performers with real technical knowledge leaving at low competency people staying
not a small start-up biotech company anymore.  very heavy with layers and layers management.  it is hard to get a decision made without multiple levels of people feeling they need to give input.
demanding work schedule.  heavy on administrative workload.  approvals are required for nearly everything as the company is very paranoid about all compliance guidelines.

poor leadership from the top on down.  relied too much on a few blockbusters now nearing patent expiry, current pipeline prospects overstated. too much uncertainty going forward.  unclear vision. too many projects dead in the water allowed to go forward with costly staff.  undermanned.  limited advancement opportunities - who you know more important than what you know.
contractors have no benefits or security. can be let go at any time. large bureaucracy to get things you need, like computer, access to erp system(taking 7 weeks).
the economy has been tough and amgen is not immune to its effects.  downsizing is common in these times but employees are compensated for their time here.
highly political decision system: decision making in corridor after meeting by a gang of good friends. few opportunities for growth and promotion. little appetite for innovation.
management is not very stable or great. amgen should be more informed when putting people in power.

very poor senior leadership, they have no idea what staff actually do.   managers once could make decisions, now they are all worried about the repercussions.  constantly making the same mistakes over and over due to arrogance from the top down.
thick middle management, opportunities for growth
some of the financial systems used were cumbersome or inefficient. there a lot of channels/approvals to go through if you want to implement a change to a current system.

a lot of unecessary office politics. leadership more command-and-control than collaborative. despite being an innovative industry, the many compliance issues and linear processes tend to stiffle innovative initiatives, pity.

lack of decision makers in upper management, weak pipeline,  you now have to interview for any promotional movement (no longer based on merit or achievement), low employees moral and lack of excitement...
not as many opportunities and/or growth are available within the company.
i had a bad director.
continous change of path, training and outside certifications should be a must. takes a long time to have an oportunity to escalate positions if you are not part of one of the central offices.

sales data is not reported accurately and therefore, you get screwed on your bonus.  management won't acknowledge sales data reporting issues.  amgen puts quotas on # of people who must get a bad year end review, even if it's not warranted.

inexperienced management - they are educated but 9 out of 10 lack practical interpersonal skills.  the decision making process (if there is one) is the weakest i have ever seen and the concensus building that occurs is merely an excuse for no one to be held accountable.  adminttedly the environment is complex with global considerations, but senior leadership represents the """"smartest group of dumb people"""" i have ever... run accross.
slow growth and low attrition limit career options  management plays chess with individual careers
the company has changed a lot since i joined it over four years ago.   it had a small pharma/biotech feel, that has all changed
tough competetion in order to get an interview/ saturated market for few job placements.
amgen is too big and thousand oaks is the only good location
i felt a lot of work
too many managers and sales reps
top heavy, no empowerment, slow decision making
allocation of resources is poor, intense working hours.  great place for young, single workforce.  not balanced for working families.

it projects tends to be underestimated in terms of scope, effort.   previous cio is from navy. likes big bang project implementation, fast and furious, resulting in chaotic projects.  outsource to ibm in one shot without transiting well, resulted in lower service quality or total loss of service.
there are no downsides working for amgen.
everything else, esp the management or so called leaders
micro-managed to death - slave driver  too much ride alongs - 2-4 days a month  too much managers - 1 manager per 7 rep  no work life balance - lots of on line training, conference calls
i tired to change direction but there were no opportunities for me to do that, no programs in place to try something new
not a lot of opportunity for growth.  you have to follow a specific job plan.
sometimes not very good mentoring for highly ranked employees which is why i left
the company is still developing since it is only 30 year old. it needs to expand its international market. it is better to build some r&d sites outside of usa.

too many inappropriately promoted exec directors and directors. promotions confuse great individual contributor skills with ability to manage others. much fierce internal competition.  who you report to really matters here.  high percentage of really sub-standard support staff and associates.
the issue that amgen is facing is the lack of promotional opportunities.  they have a lot of middle management that has been here forever and not top performers.
no career; promotions are arbitrary and unrelated to work or merit.
it is difficult for a non phd to get promoted to the phd level.  however, people are compensated well at the associate levels.

poor stock performance, very political culture, few opportunities for advancement, incompetent management, the compensation and promotion system feels gamed. good people are not recognized. if you are not ex-navy or ex-merck, you have a job, not a career. good luck getting people to listen to your ideas. many people feel they have never worked so hard for so little praise, advancement and compensation in their... careers.

coming from an engineering background, my position is far from technical.  processes to get certain tasks accomplished can be daunting/frustrating.   salary is on the low end for computer science/computer engineering graduates but the company makes up for this with great benefits.

i agree with whoever posted a few comments down: annual performance reviews this year were more horrible than ever. doing a great job is worthless. amgen has a culture that dwells on weaknesses instead of developing strengths. lack of career development. instead i hear countless stories of how good people are being blocked from moving around... i see a toxic environment for many. i see aggressive and passive-aggressive behavior from management. extreme top down management, better no one speaks up or else. consensus forming has gone out the door years ago. i've had 3 managers so far and have yet to see anyone who actually has managerial talent. i see the best people leave, and i will be one of them soon.

advancement seems to be less dependent on excellent job performance than it does on favoritism.  requests for vacation are frowned upon as though you are abandoning the company, and it is not uncommon to be asked if you still need a certain day off, several weeks after the vacation was approved (the implication obviously being you should cancel your pre-approved vacation).    each employee's end-of-year ranking is based more on meaningless metrics that have little or nothing to do with productivity.  any hint of criticism, no matter how constructive or logical, to the ideas of leadership or leadership's favorites is seen as having a negative attitude and not being a team player.  this reputation sticks with employees forever.  the result of this is a site-wide mouth shut policy with no open dialogue.    much work occurs on projects for which the only purpose is to keep people busy.      the employee review and internal hiring processes are highly secretive, with most outcomes coming as complete surprises to everyone.  when an outcome is negative, affected employees are usually not told, and must rely on hearing it through the grape-vine from their peers.
poor work/life balance  minimal promotion opportunities  minimal personal development opportunities
communication could be better between senior management and staff.  starting salaries seem low.
heavy workload  may be losing 'entrepreneurial' spirit
limited career advancement at south san francisco site, budget cut backs limited travel and conference opportunities, lack of quality projects
career advancements is difficult to achieve after entering the company

- is has been outsourced to ibm.  due to various issues on both sides, the transition has been messy and people are leaving amgen or ibm fairly often  - since people in is are not sure of their job stability anymore, people are leaving for other companies  - new changes in is are difficult due to process issues within amgen and ibm so things are put on hold  - most of the feedback from peers and your personal... assessment is not read since reviews, merit increases and so forth are decided among managers before the feedback process starts.  - espp discount went down from 15% to 5%.  - tuition reimbursement is harder to get but you still get 10k/yr
career advancement and quality of management in lower levels
it is tough to move up and get promoted without a degree from a prestigious university.

only game in town; in case of job loss need to move; lots of downsizing and budget constraints lately; very little career development; constant & perpetual management changes; takeover target for big pharma
promotion and leadership opportunities are few.  project teams seem to be stacked with the same people rather then promoting diversity of opinion,    very head office centric
easy to get burned out on one's job

very low morale and very little concern at the top on improving morale.  lots of cutbacks for the workers while senior management spends like the old days.  very much a division between senior management and the rest of the company.

the following are specific to the fremont site and do not apply to other amgen sites:  -lack of empowerment for people below director level  -decisions from senior management take too long to make  -management skills of middle management is very poor (too much of a formality, i.e. just someone to sign your timecard)  -lack of mentors to support career development of junior staff  -uncertainty of activity at site (no... new products or projects coming to the site)

company does not reward productivity.  management never lets the truth get in the way of a """"good story"""".  many of the midlevel managers have been there a long time and are not open to better ideas and are not willing to take risk.
since the anemia crash there has been no opportunities for people within amgen to move ahead in the company.  the company is not concerned about its employees, but only the bottom dollar.
be ready for assessments and field rides.  although this is now the norm across the industry.

sometimes you have to fight for what you rightfully deserve in regards to getting promoted.     there are many managers without any managerial experience. so they just hover over you all the time. and some managers have very high expectations from their team members while others are pleased with their teams' mediocre work.

amgen management makes much of their openness to feedback and input from all levels of staff, all the while exhibiting a patronizing attitude toward staff and ignoring that same feedback and input.  i feel disconnected from the decisions of management and the direction of the company.  inconsistencies in promotion and compensation decisions between groups has lead to resentments between coworkers, and an... unwillingness to promote within my own group has lead to resentment against management.
you can get lost and not get anywhere unless you have a phd.
senior management is not that great  many decisions that are made by the senior management are not well taken by the people in the company, also senior management is over compensated.
compensation, not paid for performance

amgen's gotten big but still tries to integrate all of the sites, and so having to videoconference every meeting gets quite cumbersome.      too many layers of management too - it can make things a little too hierarchical at times.
there are alot of contractors and consultants

as amgen gets larger, it needs to work even harder for it to maintain the 'old biotech style'. it grew too fast from 2001-2006 and realized in the last couple years that more people do not directly translate to greater success. however, it must make smart investments in the long term. denosumab is the direct result of major discoveries in bone biology made by amgen scientists 15 years ago.     amgen provides a... scientific career path which is very competitive and provides real opportunities for career growth. however, compensation is not always on par with peers in areas outside research and development. greater incentives will continue to keep the best scientists at amgen.

as nice as it is to work somewhere fun, the """"fun"""" factor seems to get in the way of actually getting work done, which i personally find really annoying.  the slackers within the company are generally tolerated well, and they are able to use the dreaded """"hr"""" card too often with little cause.  for example, if you tell an employee that she hasn't performed her task, it is not uncommon that the employee may cry then... take you to hr for being insensitive.  the whole issue can turn into a case about how you treated her rather than the initial issue that she wasn't doing her job. i've never seen hr take action on this type of complaint, but it's certainly possible that they may have to if the circumstances are right based on liberal ca law.

it is not run like a business nor are the decisions based on financial principles. no roi is applied nor are previous decisions brought under review for whether the goals or objectives were met. the career path is limited for those who support the business. even research personnel and those involved in the product have limited upward mobility unless you find a mentor or advocate. the move to outsource will be one... that bites them in the end.

it can be very hard to get promoted; too top heavy; can be bureaucratic.  a lot of constant re-organizations; one year, had 6 bosses.  many senior management hires from outside the company have difficulty adjusting to amgen culture and giving clear direction & goals, which affects staff.
red tape, things move slow at times. it has been difficult to assess the direction of the company over the past few years. this means layoffs and instability, but moral seems to be back up.
no career opportunities or advancement

the environment is very political and it is harder to get basic things done than it should be. there is a lot of churn and inefficiency due to unclear lines of authority and decision-making. too many policies and processes and too much policing. it often feels like there are more people looking for what's wrong than ways to make it right.

you get bucketed very quickly and there is no way to move up very high in the organization from very low no matter what you do.    these people got lucky with a few very profitable drugs but are totally clueless about drug discovery.  you will not learn from your superiors -- you will teach them.
too much bureaucracy...hard to get anything done!  very hierarchical.  no recognition of competence...too much politics!!!  incompetent leadership.

even though i worked there for 14 years, i never really felt appreciated for my dedication and hard work.  when kevin shear became our ceo we became numbers instead of names.  it was a hugh culture shock.  unfortunately, upper management doesn't seem to recognize when departmental managers are only looking out for themselves.  it hurts moral and decreases productivity.
meeting constant critical deadlines with limited resources.

besides management not listening to employees, there are alot of politics that need to be navigated. you can work as hard as anyone and be the smartest guy in the world and it will only get you about half way in this company.
very top heavy, with too many-mid level managers who are a hinderance for advancement
cost of living in surrounding community; stock has not performed well in the past 2 years, however that is all about to change.

the company grew so fast that people were being promoted every couple of years whether they deserved it or not.  this lead to a situation where people were promoted into management positions even though they were not management material.  a lot of people have left the company because of poor managment.  those of us that are still there are subjected to some managers that are incompetent and behave in an immoral and... unethical fashion.       there are a lot of situations where a lower level employee has zero visibility and chance for advancement because higher level employees take all the credit for work they didn't perform. due to favoritism that takes place in some departments, an atmosphere is created wherein employees that are being abused feel that they can't take any action for fear of being fired.    the opportunities for advancement are very limited now due to the current company environment.

the venal people who are predominant, competitive culture, hypocrisy. if you work for someone who is winning the internal political fight, watch out. i've never been treated so shabbily in a corporate environment. what's really heartbreaking, confusing, and ultimately dysfunctional is that there is so much that is good and that the hype is first class, so it can take awhile to figure things out. the crash is very... hard.

its easy to become just a cog in a big wheel at this company.  there is also a tendency for projects to get bogged down in lots of process.  if you are not a scientist then your role is likely one more of support so job duties may not be as exciting or challenging than positions in other companies.
work load is high and rewards are ok

incompetent senior management who worry only about stock price and profits (yet the stock price hasn't changed in years).  amgen grew too fast and didn't build a strong infrastructure to support a big company.  layoffs.  everything moves too slow here and it takes years to finish a project that other companies could do in months.  too many changes that don't have any real benefit.  there is no discipline in this... company and everyone is treated with """"kid gloves"""" to prevent from hurting anyone's feelings.

the company is rebuilding and there is much uncertainty as to how things will look in the near term.  long term i do believe the company will do very well, but there will be much angst between now and then.  many great people have left voluntarily or involuntarily in the past year and it is a shame to see a loss of such talent.

ansys is relatively a good company to work for, however, the company grew far too quickly for its own good. many, many, many policies and procedures are archaic relics of a bygone era. in the past 10 years, the company has basically only grown via acquisition of other companies, with no real internal development. the licensing structure is at least a decade out of date. most of the time, the answer to the customer... is """"no"""" or """"you can't do that unless you pay x amount more"""".    every department except for sales and r&d is understaffed.    personal projects.  a large part of your workload (and 35% of your yearly review) revolves around projects that are generally only vaguely related to the actual function of the department.  most of these are pure busy work, while others involve trying to develop procedures for people in other departments. your supervisor will receive most of the credit for a successful project. if another department does not want to go along with a project (i.e. the it department can't spend man hours or money on a bus ops idea) you will be held responsible for that. the most infamous ongoing project is the """"team competition"""" where you compete against other colleagues via quizzes on procedures, crossword puzzles, and 6th grade science/art projects. one of these worthwhile activities was to make a macaroni portrait of the director of bus ops,... you can't make this stuff up.    bus ops is ran as the personal fiefdom of the director, who absolutely does not care about anything other than his (very large) ego, and discussing sports. (pro tip, if for some reason you want to work there, make sure you know everything about baseball),  several years before my time at ansys was over, he actually forbade any discussion of """"office morale"""". one of his catch phrases was """"you can always find a different job."""" despite this, you will be expected to drink the kool aid and show unwavering enthusiasm for the company, the customer, and, especially, your personal projects.    nepotism is rampant in the the hiring and promotion of the staff.  the """"supervisors"""" busy themselves seeking the director's favor  and working on personal projects (there's that phrase, again) instead of actually leading their teams.  in order to have time to complete these projects, the actual supervisor duties have been delegated to senior crcs (who, with few exceptions, are personal friends or a spouse of a supervisor). if you know any of them, by all means, you should submit a resume.    pay raises and bonuses are insultingly low, barely above inflation. when it is time for your yearly review, you will almost certainly rate a consistent 2 to 3, on a 5 -point scale.  for every criterion of the review. it is an open secret in the company that the director has instructed his underlings to not rate anyone a 3.5 or above, unless your project catches the praise of upper management. your supervisor, who likely did nothing but listen to you report on the work you did on the project, will receive a higher score than you for your work.  no other department rates their staff in this manner.    every trivial piece of information is treated as top secret, and secrets are traded almost as a commodity amongst the entire department.  a culture of backstabbing also exists.  my advice is to keep your ears open and your mouth closed.

everyone is promoted on an arbitrary basis.  the pro listed above creates a considerable con - everybody is bad at their job because they are promoted based on their performance at their current job, not because of their potential at the job they get promoted to.  hard working engineers who are willing to put in crazy hours and forego life outside of the plant are rewarded with higher positions but make terrible... managers who expect equivalent effort from their subordinates who don't have the same values.  good, productive engineers are left behind because they don't work the hours, while less than capable engineers get moved up because they are at work before their managers get to work and after their managers leave.  the review system is unproductive because it is based on the amount of work done not the quality of work or the employee's ability to work with team members.  there is no structured system for engineers to move up in pay scale.  there is no definition for production engineer, engineer i, engineer ii, engineer iii, and senior engineer and these titles are arbitrarily distributed.  you won't get the title unless you request it.  they don't offer promotions.  really there is no inspiration to work for adm and the longer you stay the less motivated you will be to advance.

cons there are not to many except for your belief in zero accidents. i believe 98 maybe 99% of all accidents can be prevented and that most are human error. unfortunately things do break and what can happen will happen. i have seen people targeted after an incident that wasn't even a lost time accident and fired just afterwards for something not related supposedly. it has the reputation now so people are afraid to... report anything because they know what will come next. i have never had to sign a paper anywhere that i have ever worked that stated i could not hold them liable if an accident occurred and if i did not sign it i would not be hired. though i know the adm is 100 % safer than when i first worked there that does not give me confidence that this is a safe place to work at. i think accountability by deniability shows a lack of integrity. myself i personally think that anyone who deals with workmans comp is in for a world of hurt for they care nothing for the victim whether one seeks legal action or not. if one does seek legal action beware because it will follow that individual. if one is careful  and follows your instructions to the t and are self-disciplined to consciously be aware of where they are, identifying thoroughly on safety sheets all existing hazards in that area & appropriate course of action to removing hazards or appropriate ppe while focused to job at hand, their odds of going home without incident is a strong 99%. safety is a team effort so strive for perfection but be realistic that 1 to 2 % cannot be prevented. i am sorry but the smell isn't all that pleasant  but i did get use to it.
very well known of micromanagement

swing shift was not easy with a family. worked seven days of seconds, off 24 hours, work seven nights of thirds, off for 48 hours, work seven days of first shift, then you get four days out. it's not too bad when you get adjusted to it, but for me having a wife and kid, it has sucked. management doesn't want to listen to you when you tell them that there's a problem, but when that problem gets out of hand and stops... production it's the employee's fault. safety only matters if it won't cost anything to do. if there's a problem with the tracks, and you tell your supervisor, he tells you he'll pass it up the line but keep using that track. when you keep using the track and cars derail, it's your fault because your supervisor never passed it up to management. communication is non existent. when the superintendent comes out of his office, he doesn't know what anything is or where anything is. he will also yell at you for doing something wrong, when he doesn't know if it's wrong or right in the first place. if you take your concerns higher than him, that he doesn't know what is going on, they tell you not to worry about it. it's a very discouraging system.

really, only cons are salary, hours, and technology. salary is ok, one can definitely be comfortable with what is earned, but still lags behind the industry standard. you could argue though that this lower salary is traded for job security. other firms if you don't do well, you get canned. here, you would stay on and get several chances before being fired.    the other con is hours, and i mean the sense that if it's... dead in the office, you're still expected to stick around. with technology today, much of your job can be done outside of the office. however, it seems there's still the attitude that if you're not in the office, you're not working.    finally, technology. the systems we use to track contracts, contacts, a/r, everything is decades old. and i mean decades. information is not easy to access. even the simplest things like looking up a contract balance can be a daunting task if you don't have the right permissions or know what commands to type. however, this is a known problem in the company, and millions of dollars are being spent to get us updated. by the time this gets rolled out though, the tech will likely be outdated. i won't hold my breathe.

i find it hard to believe that adm has earned so much success as an agricultural giant by running process facilities like the way the hazleton plant is run. there is such a disconnect between management and hourly employees to a level that creates a very unsafe working environment. most safety issues that are brought to management's attention are dis-regarded until a serious incident happens that can't be """"pushed... under the rug"""" and after the employee is blamed for the incident, then the proper engineering changes are made. we are forced to work all major holidays without so much as a thank you, while management gets to celebrate those holidays with their families. if you are seriously considering a career at adm cocoa hazleton you might also want to brush up on your firefighting skills, we are not allowed to call 911 in the event of a fire because upper level management doesn't want deal with the publicity, so we are handed water squirting bottles and off to the fight! none of us have had any proper training to be put in situations like this, no respirators, no nothing, but if you do pursue a job position at this location you should have plenty of time for external training because your family will leave you!

where to begin: definitely under payed. provide too many services for a under staffed and under payed employee. a co-worker has really no mechanical skills but a great salesman, was almost written up due too a customer calling g.m. about a battery not being installed. he was told do whatever it takes  no matter what! i don't agree.  ungrateful customer's  that are extremely impatient, rude and do not understand the... difference between a curtisy and a required installation exspecialy with only one other counter sales person at 5 pm . when the amount of traffic threw the store is at its peak. non existent sick time?  shows we have it on pay stub? so we can't use it and can not cash it out, why show it if it doesn't exist... 2 faced management praise you when your there but soon as you turn your back ready to through you under the bus?  i see our ceo got a 1.5 million dollar bonus how do even justify a 17 cent raise i was appalled and disgusted, i was told that i received the biggest raise ( wow)!!! still waiting on my extra mile award and bonus check prevented someone returning parts that where supposed to be installed on a customer's vehicle. i was confused, i was almost written up basically got a verbal warning for my actions,  then nominated for the extra mile award?  i don't understand management also the fackest people i have ever meet ! how do expected loyalty to a company from a employee when you pay them less then a mcdonald's employee? employee has you provide skilled service that requires a lot of of foot work dealing with rude impatient customer's  with the wrong information that was given by customer and getting the business as they slam the parts on the counter talking about ,you gave me the wrong parts....no, you gave me the wrong information! ( do you know how many people come up asked for a part and can't tell you anything about there vehicle including the yr they point to the parking and say that car) worked like a full-time position work five days to get 25 hrs it cost me half that week just to go to work!!! employee get real tired of your rouge management playing jeckle and hyde with there money (hrs) plus quality of personal life makeing terrible money personal life in the gutter mean while the salary manger working min 50- 80 hrs a week?????

where do i start. who manages determines the place of work to be enjoyable or a nightmare. the wrong management scares away good employees and replaces them with new part-timers who may or may not have any car knowledge. management (and upper management) only care about the numbers on paper and will cut hours, forbid overtime, while simultaneously tell you that the store looks like crap and you need to be selling... this! or putting away freight faster! or do planos! all while there's two people up front on the counter for most of the day. low morale due to all the drama and backstabbing from (bad) store managers. always something to complain about, not much in words of praise to the employees. pay is meh: i've worked 3 years and have had great reviews yet my pay raise total has been under .75 cents. in three years. i've been praised that i would be good for a manager spot since i worked there for 6 months and all i got were excuses: """"we hired somebody else."""" even though i was actively completing training. """"you're going to school."""" there are part-time managers. """"now we're training somebody else."""" i've given up, it's not worth the extra what, $2 an hour? all the drama and and increasing pressure to try to do any multitasking when there's only two or three people in the store make it a crappy place to work. i come in expecting the environment and culture to just keep getting worse.

to start with, i was made to wait 7 months to be offered full-time employment, and that was only after i had bugged the managers for months about it, finally getting them to relent when i had threatened to quit. as a part timer, i worked over 40 hours a week, and sometimes more than 50, but ever since i was finally made part time i've had to struggle to make 32-36 hours a week. the managers and most dms don't care for disabled people such as myself and don't compensate us to make our job slightly easier, and i've had to work each and every day that i was sick. for the last 5 months, my paychecks have been late and i've had to force myself every month to borrow money from family just to make ends meet. my store manager has repeatedly attempted to give me less than the 32 hours a week that i am required, by law, to be given, and it was only after having a 45 minute over the phone argument with the regional manager that i was able to get these schedules fixed. and as if all of this wasn't enough, we red-shirts don't get regular days off, even upon request, unlike the grey-shirts. we get our schedules weekly, and for some of us (such as myself) we don't get next week's schedule until saturday, when the store manager finally gets around to making them, and to make it worse, the hours are all over the place. one day you could be working 7:30 am - 5:00 pm, the next could be 12:00 pm - 6:00 pm, and the day after that could be 8:00 am - 6:00 pm.

my number one pet peeve is the operating systems that autozone uses, it is a new and constant battle everyday to help customers by utilizing the operating systems. the gui is great, but the rest of it is mostly crud, countless dead hyperlinks, overzealous restrictions that make it difficult to use the system, and redundant/useless data. autozone doesn't have enough servers which causes huge amounts of latency... therefore causing transactions an such to timeout. the server centers do not have backup generators/systems which halt any digital interface usage between employee/customer. from what i can gather the operating systems have remained more or less the same from decades ago, with frequent patches (band-aids) to keep the systems running. huge amounts of time and efficiency, which equals money, are lost to these problems alone. the store i work at doesn't use modern high speed internet, it uses old school two wire dsl. i'm indescribably frustrated by cell phone usage excluding store and commercial manager, it's too much of a distraction. lazy employees are not disciplined, causing the many of the hard working employees to leave. we are expected to cram all sorts of products down customers throats whether they want it or not; if we fail to do so everyone in the store gets in trouble.

witt and hours.  plan and simple.  customers come, customers go, some are great, some not so much, but they all become your priority, which is what it should be.  az portrays itself as such a customer, employee, and family orientated company, i fell hook, line, and sinker.   i took the store management position after much thought and personal struggle of my time spent with my family and the job and customers i... absolutely adored.  the thought of not being there hurt as bad as the thought of less time with my family.  in the end, i took the position.  the job, the work, the time (usually 60-70 hours a week) is hard, but i push through, my family and my work family depend on me.  but to work 70 hours a week, do my job with complete efficiency, and be good at what i do, and i am damn good at my job,  being constantly beat down over packets of grease and lube and extras the customers don't always want and/or need,  is a soul crushing thing.  70 hours away from my children and husband, completely loyal and happy customers, happy employees, and better actual earnings cash wise than the previous years, i'm still being told its not good enough because my team have not sold enough check out challenges, witt packets, or add ons, or signed up enough new people to a rewards card in a town so small, we've signed most people up 2 or 3 times!  i don't need a pat on the back for the good i do, but i don't need a knife in it either over a number they think should be higher.   i love my job, can't imagine my life without it, but sadly think i'm not far from stepping away from what was something i used to look forward to.

sadly the cons will vastly outweigh on a company and job i feel could be one of the best ones to work for.  autozone doesn’t care if you have any kind of experience whatsoever, which is fine. i have no problems with that. the issues arises, when others talk and come to find out others are making as much as a dollar more than them and they have experience. not sure what they are basing their scales on. sales forecast... models are pretty decent to obtain unless you get a very hungry dm in your area and things can change drastic overnight for what they want to see done. hours being cut. the company pushes and pushes and pushes witt, phone answer in 3 especially. there’s no telling how much is lost though due to customers coming in and there’s only 3 to 4 in line which isn’t bad. the phone is ringing now and your one other employee is outside doing a battery. now you have impatient customers and two have walked out. 20-30 dollar potential sales from each person that just left that would have easily paid the small hourly wage they would have paid a part time person to be there to assist.

one complaint out weighs hand fulls of satisfied customers.  they are more concerned with making one customer happy than keeping a single father of 2 employed. they preach """"wittdtjr"""" what it takes to do the job right, but if you teach a customer how to fix their automotive problem without selling them parts you are wrong. i am a firm believer in, """"give a man a fish, he'll eat for at day. teach a man to fish and... he'll eat for the rest of his life."""" i've owned a lot of old used cars which require more maintenance than a car fresh from the lot.  over a period of 2 months i saved upwards of 10 individual customers hundreds of dollars on parts they didn't need by listening to what issues they were having with their car. instead of selling them a part they didn't need i would teach them how to fix what they have. which is no doubt what it takes to do the job right. as a former active duty service member i had made an inappropriate comment to a current service member of another branch. i am not saying i am right for making the comment, but after 5 years of service you get used to ribbing the other branches back and forth. the service member filed a formal complaint instead of just firing an insult back. autozone decided to terminate me. no second chance, no warning, slap on the wrist, nothing. autozone knew that my wages were being garnished for child support which my children need me to pay. this act of putting the customer first after one incident shows that autozone does not care about its employees, nor do they stand by their, """"what it takes to do the job right"""" motto. all autozone cares about is selling replica  parts made in china to increase their profits. way to represent america autozone. they don't care if the customer gets their car fixed, they just care that the customer buys replacement parts from autozone.

the pay sucks. i was making $10/hr as a parts sales manager the sales people made around $8-9 at most. i worked hard as i have work ethic and dont leave things unfinished meaning i was the one that always got called when other called in and was the one expected to do other's work that they didnt bother to finish. the busy nature of the stores and low pay cause alarming turn over and the people they bring in dont... want to work already on top of the low pay so it exacerbates the problem
retail. changing batteries, headlights bulbs. management always changing. slow advancement.
pay and the """"managers"""" think they are the best.

understaffed(2 people on the counter, one outside most of the day) poor promotion pay, leadership, district managers. lost of sight into what matters. turnover. stock buy back, could finance an extra 40 hours per day with what’s spent on stock buy back(several assumptions, 10 employees per store, each full time). pledge (it contradicts itself.) store managers are free payroll, upper doesn’t care about your family.

you have to buy your own uniform from the company, with prices that are over retail for similar clothes.  management is way out of touch with their employees.  ceo complains of having less profit due to """"demand for higher wages"""".  raises (once per year) at my store that consistently hit or was very near target goals were barely enough to cover inflation.  health insurance is terrible.      busy stores that deal with... many """"backyard mechanics"""" are significantly understaffed as hours are based on sales that they're hoping to get from an average diy customer, and neglect to take customer count into consideration.  also, they care little to nothing if you actually know how to help your customers diagnose a car, since they assume their computer software will do it for you (it doesn't).  i was literally told by my regional hr manager that autozone doesn't recognize ase certification as something that i could get a raise for.  instead he said that is something that i should put on my resume.   great advice, willie banks, now i have a much higher paying job!    the commercial program is a joke.  in metro detroit where parts suppliers are bountiful, somehow autozone thinks that charging 10% under retail is going to be competitive, and then question why the program is doing so poorly.  not to mention having minimally staffed delivery drivers putting parts delivery well over an hour in most cases.     if you are hired and have the skills to work on cars (actually, even if you don't) you are expected to be a parking lot mechanic.  even if it is -10 degrees out, you are required to put batteries, light bulbs, and wiper blades on customers cars.    the only thing senior and regional management were concerned about were numbers.  if they would treat their employees like people that are looking for a liveable wage, autozone would be doing much better with people who were happy to come to work every day.  instead, most of the staff turned to other forms of relief and were stealing as much as they could without getting caught.
reverse discrimination. had 3 store managers fired for stealing.  completed all the classes and prerequisites for store manager but saw unqualified people get the job then get fired.
management uses lies to manipulate employees. culture of lack of accountability throughout the company.
there are not many females that work at autozone. so when customers walk into the store, i get weird looks or people won’t let me help them due to me being female.
having to use our free service  on bad weathers
the base pay is absolutely horrible. there’s a lot of downtime i don’t like it because i like to work and i’m always trying to find somthinf. to do to keep  me  busy
pay  lack of advancement opportunities  computer system has problems

-pay is low for having to constantly give out automotive advice and knowledge  -complaints of sales metrics  -limited hours   -customers come in waves; you'll always be under or over staffed given the time of day  -obd2 g-force/accelerometer tracking in cars but always in a rush  -pay for your own uniform and replacement when it gets stained  -""""customer is always right""""
problems with management. when staring off they only pay minimum wage and they start you off at part time. can be stressful with the amount of traffic coming in and out of the store
i made very little money doing the gm’s job duties most of the time.
sometimes dealing with customers can be difficult.
sometimes they could be slow to promote
part time for me was full time for others. 35 hour """"part time"""" weeks we're really annoying to deal with.
working till 10pm then opening at 7am. unsteady schedule. low pay. favoritism. dealing with angry customers.
manager did not know how to run store. was never on time to open

depends on store, customers can be difficult at times but all in all not terrible.     we are not mechanics! (customers tend to think so.)     for the love of god if you're a guy and can't install your own wiper blade that's pretty pathetic.
hard to get a full time position

loud customers that think they are right when they are clearly mistaken are a big problem in this line of work. if you cannot let someone know that they are mistaken without being offensive or can let it roll off your shoulders. this is not the job for you.
the pay is not that great i bearly  make it i mean i struggle

too many power struggles between the staff and the immediate management staff. very unprofessional tons to the point of being racist or biased towards people of color. no room for growth for certain people no matter what they knew or did for advancement.
little work/life balance; zero support from upper management; inability to fire ineffective employees;
forced to receive pay by debit card thats not valid with any bank, then charged $5 per withdraw

as a part timer, you get a job but the only benefit that you get is a discount on store brand product. if it is not store brand, you will not get the discount. it is hard too to take breaks if there is a lot of customers in the store, but that is also so that the customers do not have to wait.

- upper level management regularly throwing a fit to lower management about sales as if they control who and how many come in the door.    - only care about selling little non-app  items with the big job (brake grease with brake pads, bulb grease with bulbs, anti corrosive grease and felt pads with batteries).    - constantly scolding for not selling wittdtjr (what it takes to do the job right) items. like brake... pads with brake rotors. or serpentine belts with alternators.    - always complaining about not enough sales of """"check out challenge"""" (on sale items on top of check out counter like fuel treatment, car fresheners, shop towels).    - says """"don't take no for an answer"""", """"must sell the item"""". if a customer tells me they don't want something, i will not argue.    - must answer phone within three rings. i'm sorry but if i'm busy with an in-store customer, i will not pause helping them to answer the phone and help an on-phone customer. that is just plain rude and i will not do it.    - recognizes hard work but does not take action on it (as in promotions, raises, more hours).    - low pay even with experience or college degree.    - hires """"automotive clueless"""" people off the street into management position before offering current employees the promotion position.
the employees who give little to no effort make everybody's job harder. back-to-back closing/opening shifts are not fun at all.
everything about this place sucks
having to be nice to customers who think we should do mechanic work for them for free
low salary for tons of responsibilities and work
they want you to bring sales up on certain products every month but does not offer commission at all
poor pay. obviously being retail you have some rude customers to say the least. mostly the pay is the problem.
frequent hour cuts, upper management limits what you can do at the store level.
must answer phones and help customers at the same time which can be stressful at times.
hours sometimes are tight and training is kind of minimal but again you learn it all on the job
no career advancement opportunity.  only get holiday off.  you still have to come in christmas eve.

little to no work-life balance. company keeps district managers that have no people skills and no ability to drive sales or managers in place way to long and causes detrimental results to employees and business.  providing services that can be time consuming for free, with few employees to provide them. working outside in harsh weather conditions. associate to customer ratio is allot of times not compatible.
for the amount of work we do even the free work for our customers we don't get paid enough for everything we do

alot of walking and movement, some people can be rude.

high turnover, call-ins or no shows on truck day or weekends can be stressful

compared to other retail jobs you have to wear many more hats here. there are no dedicated cashiers, dedicated inventory managers/maintainers, no cleaning staff, no restocking staff, everyone does everything. battery installs and wipers, sweeping/mopping floors and cleaning bathrooms, running registers, auditing registers and safes, always tons of push product like fuel system cleaners, and extra add ons for pretty... much everything sold, stocking merchandise, verifying and restocking returns, there's much more but you get the point. if you're looking for a simple cashier job or sales floor job coming from a big box store, this probably isn't the job for you.
the strictness on uniform, company mottos, phone shops and the system on how they determine on cutting hours.
it is a retail job, pay is not good.   expect to be a salesman. management will post store revenues and expect you to up-sell.
this region's upper management is lacking anything but lip service. there's no room for advancing in this area as district management has been there over twenty years.

they force you, yes, force you to sell packets of grease and if you don't reach a certain percentage, they will write you up. the company solely cares about harassing their customers with a million questions: do you have a rewards card? would you like one? i have fuel system cleaner on sale, would you like some? we recommend you purchase the brake lube for you pads & pins..oh you'd like the lube? well we have a $5... brake bundle, you get this this blah blah. get my drift? i will never recommend anyone to work here.
not enough pay for the work you put in. when in a growing commercial store they want you to succeed but do not help give you the proper tools to do so.
4 hour shifts  pay a little higher than minimum wage

they don't care about their red shirts. if you are part time and a red shirt you basically receive anything for your extra efforts. even if you work the holidays, you don't get paid holiday pay. there are really no incentives to work hard. they want you too take all these tests throughout your time there and they want you to go above and beyond for the customer, yet they won't go above and beyond for you. lastly... raises are trash.
not enough pay and hours

boredom. low pay. unstable hours. terrible customers

they don't pay what your worth.  the get problems solved at company level, takes forever.  you strive for diamond accounts then when you have themy the company seems to start pulling back on resources for those accounts. drivers, vehicles, etc.

confused. they want you to wear dress pants and polishable shoes to install batteries in the parking lot. learn that light bulbs and maintenance chemicals do not belong at the front of the store for so many reasons.

store manager was overpaid for how very little help we got as employees. slow hours were fine, we got stuff done, but busy hours with a psm and a couple red shirts was hell, even when the store manager was working too. spent most of the time in the office, only came out to check something or when we asked for help. store manager stayed at the counter until it slowed down enough, then went right back to the office.... had a lot customers complain about the store manager in a short period of time. also, sm and dm never rewarded employees but loved to reprimand for any little thing.

they promise you full time and it will never happen. they say they will move you up quick. nope. they will give it to someone of there same ethnic back ground. not an equal opportunity employer by any means!
pay was low, your on your feet all day, lack of training, lack of upward mobility.

if i could rate them with zero stars i would. i worked there for over a year i worked 10 times harder then anyone in the store and i knew more about cars then the managers we had at the store. they refused to give me a opportunity to move up and gave me a 16 cent raise after a year. so i became a manager somewhere else and i'm still a manager over a year later. the best choice i made was leaving that company.   the management that az has is horrible and the district managers are extremely lazy and don't wanna pay people for what they are worth.   benefits are terrible and the hours they hand you are trash and they don't wanna work with you because it's an in convince to them and the company.   worst about the company is they are very understaffed and have a very high turn over rate!
bad location, high crime area.

i personally felt held back, more than once,  in my position held. i worked twice as hard as some of the men and was under paid and intentionally held back from promotion due to my gender. i have a well rounded knowledge of automotive symtoms, problems, parts and services necessary for servicing and repairing. i was qualified for commercial sales and had proven myself to be so. yet the previous position holder, who... failed at the position and eventually resigned, made nearly 4 dollars more an hour than i did. although i had excelled where he had failed. in the end to get rid of me i suspect,  i was falsely accused of theft. i was threatened with arrest without providing evidence of what they were accusing me of.
no overtime and would change store managers once a month

management thinks they own you as a person when you're logged in (slavery ended a long time ago).  they don't care about your level of education or the fact that you can speak multiple languages. you will still get the same minimum wage as everyone else. there is a big disconnect between corporation and retail. people are considered a resource and can easily be replaced by anyone who is willing to do the same job... for less or get less hours. there is no commission or bonuses based on how well the store performs, while upper management continues to encourage to sell more. still at part-time level after working for this company for nearly a year with no insurance or better base bay, after roughly a year working with them.

the job it's self has kind of a unsettling and slightly dangerous environment if you are not careful of what you are doing. pay compensation isn't that great unless you're promoted to an actual store manager.

long hours standing, no time for breaks. stores are always understaffed. company would rather save $2.00 than take care of customers. some customers are nice, the rude obnoxious ones ruin your entire day. everybody takes advantage of employees. they expect you to work on their cars for free. charge ac, disassemble the front end to install a bulb, put belts on, etc. poor pay for all you are expected to know and do.... if you like nonstop chaos, restocking store constantly, mediocre pay, apply online at autozone.com.

pay raises were meager, as in pennies per year. having been personally asked to bounce from store to store to help bring sales up, i had to fight for a decent raise. i never asked for a raise when asked to move all over the county to help these stores, i just assumed my willingness to help would be noticed. when my 5 star performance review came with a 6 cent raise after outperforming my store manager, i began... looking for a new job.

the later part of my career has not been so great. the company had gone from being very employee friendly to being greedy.  the amount of staffing hours provided to stores has been slashed to a minimum adding extra stress and overworking employees. autozone used to pay a pretty decent wage now starting wages have have slashed to a minimum as well. as far as wages go generally you get what you pay for so now the... newer employees aren't as knowledgeable as the used to be and turnover rate has increased. most stores now are under staffed and nobody wants to stick around under those conditions for min wage.

being memphis based they truly don't know how the living situation is in the silicon valley, it is hard masking ends meet with a dead end job. management promises a lot but doesn't deliver. to get anything changed, it takes months to get it approved.

terrible benefits, kip's are pushed entirely too much to the point of being absolutely forced to sell needless extra """"wittdtjr"""" (what it takes to do the job right) to customers. if you don't push this on every customer, your hours will be cut if you are part time.

low pay. they give raises about every year or so and it's laughable. the raise is based on your review score 30 points out of 30. each point is basically a cent as your raise, so max raise possible each year is 30 cents unless you plan on being a manager, which is extremely stressful and overwhelming. there is always a line of angry customers breathing down your neck waiting to pounce on any mistake you make (and... also, they usually don't know anything). you're always shorthanded and usually it's just two people working in the store every night and when it gets busy someone always has to step out to go check a battery or something and you get overwhelmed.

the pay was only $2 more than the lowest rank in the company (redshirt) and the responsibilities warranted wayyyy more money than that. you're pressured to sell bs """"add-on"""" products and are reprimanded when you don't meet the sales quota. hours get cut due to seasons (winter slows down so less hours for everyone who isn't full time). there's a lot and i mean alot of politics in the company (who you know will take... you where you want to go). stingy with how many hours are allowed to each store, for example: every store needs at least 2 ppl on the clock at all times but even when it's busiest on weekends, the system will only allow 2 ppl to run the entire store. on top of cashing out a line of customers, you then have to install a battery (for free) do a check engine light (for free) pull the overstock (no exceptions this is done every day) and then keep the store in tip-top shape. all of this with only 2 people. it can be veryyyyy stressful.  they don't support their employees as much as they should either, they will always side with the customer (fyi the customer isn't always right. wait til you get a hostile rude customer and work in a hard part of town and this customer is just being a straight ***** bag bc he's just having a bad day) . rotating hours suck too.

nothing. i loved it. i recommend this job.
